Nothing about the programme changed between final beta release and the first day of Final Release in April.       The above mentioned Steam Group is a place for free discussion about Stardrive, and its Developer that You are going to purchase a beta, abandoned game from.  The Developer will finish it on his whim alone, that could be years or decades.  These are all direct from the developer, but sadly I can't direct you to the correct site to see them, he has, or has had his Minions, delete threads full of direct quotes from Zero you simply wouldn't believe if I wrote them here, thinking I was a Troll.  I hope this shows I gave 90+ hours trying to play this game, and never completing 1 game.  Buy this game if you like someone lying to you all the time, some do I suppose.

number of helpful: 259 of 274 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Edit #2: I'll just leave this here.http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVCAn unofficial StarDrive group, where discussion is open and not censored. The Steam forum is pretty heavily moderated and the developer has a habit of deleting threads and banning people left and right before and during a big sale, so this is where people go to talk about the game however they like and not risk having their threads deleted because they didn't like the game.***I bought this game when it was in Early Access and... I thought it was amazing. Full of promises and ideas. Back then, the developper was promising updates pretty much left and right. Multiplayer was to be added to the game. Rare resources, laying mines, better diplomacy, being able to make joint operations with allies; all of these things were to be added to the game... But none -- NONE -- were implemented. The game you can buy right now is very much the same game I bought in Early Access, minus a few bugs. Hell, some core features such as the freighters are still buggy...So, that being said, is this a good game? Well, it's an okay game. I spent several hours on it so obviously it's not totally terrible. But the thing is, most of these hours (I'd say two third of them -- yes, that much) was trying mods and messing around waiting for the content update to come. When the Developper announced that he screwed up and decided the game was done and could not be updated anymore because of engine limitations, I stopped playing altogether.To make up for it, the owners of StarDrive will get a discount on his next title and access to some kind of multiplayer mini-game is going to be free. The thing is : his next game is going to be a turn-based strategy game. I bought a real-time strategy game. His next game is going to get as close to a MoO2 clone as he can. Good things for the fans, I guess, but that's not what I bought.So, to sum things up: this game is half-finished, features are lacking, it lacks polish and is very, very rough around the edges and is developped by one of the worst indy dev ever as far as PR and "I care for my customers" are involved. There are better games out there to spend your money on.But hey, that's just my opinion.***Edit #1: the multiplayer mini-game has been abandoned as well. Yes, that is yet another fail to put on Zero Sum Games resume. Also, that discount I was talking about? The one the owners of StarDrive will get? That will just be a Steam coupon with an expiration date. Great, eh? Way to tell your customers to hurry it up or screw you, Zero. Way to go indeed.

number of helpful: 491 of 559 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game had a ton of potential but was abandoned by the developer for greener pastures after he decided it would be good to start on a sequel while charging full price to everyone (including the people who have bought this unfinished project). It was initially released with a ton of bugs and still has many things that have yet to be fully fleshed out much less finished in any considerable degree. The ship designer and the battles that rarely take place are the only positives to take out of this game.The diplomacy part of the game is very shallow indeed. With races declaring war on you with little motivation beyond your empire's progression crossing a line set by their predetermined level of aggressiveness. The same goes with positive interaction. It's very much a game of watching a bar go up or down to get them to do something you want to do.Empire building is also shallow and unfinished. There is almost no internal management other than building a shallow level of building sets that make all your colonies resemble one another after only a colony or two. Rebellion takes place when your treasury drops below a certain level and only in this manner. Civilization 2 has more in depth internal management than this title.Military matters are hampered by two things: The lack of any meaningful artificial intelligence and the small tech tree present in the game. The tech tree is the smallest tree I've seen in a 4x game (and smaller than some RTS games like Rise of Nations or even Age of Empires). The AI assembles the same, tired fleet makeup and then throws it at you. This means pretty much every single game plays out the same way regardless of the galaxy size. The one saving grace in enemy behavior is that the game saves your custom ship designs and then uses them against you in subsequent games should you choose another race to play as. I would love to see other 4x games incorporate this feature into their titles so I'm faced with much more difficult fleet makeups since they were designed by myself or other players who post their designs for others to use.All in all, I'm very disappointed in not only the way this game turned out, but the developer's behavior on the steam forums once people heard he was abandoning any serious development on the game on an interview. He would ban people who warned others about the state of development and has had meltdowns on multiple gaming forums when confronted about the issue. Do not give your money to this studio. Other 4x's like Galactic Civilizations II or Distant Worlds do this genre much more of a service.

number of helpful: 204 of 217 people (94%) found this review helpful75 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Sometimes you find a game for $1.00 on HumbleBundle and think why not, I'll give it a shot.  What's the worst that could happen?  It sucks and you're out a dollar?  Don't be a fool.  Listen to me, I used to be like you...naive.  I paid the dollar, positively gitty at my thrifty yet philanthropic purchase, but I discovered there are far worse fates than not liking the game.  Oh yes, much to my dismay, I learned you could absolutely LOVE the game.  Specifically, I learned that someone, some magical gameweaver of a developer, had somehow discovered a way to craft all of my 4x RTS dreams into one perfect game.Imagine having all this only to find out after hours of gameplay that the mystical Dev had just M. Night Shyamalan'ed your♥♥♥♥♥by abandoning the game deep in development, leaving gamebreaking glitches unpatched, and giggling all the way to the bank with your hopes and dreams.  Now there will forever be a void in my heart where the finished version of this game should be.  I would've rather spent my dollar on paying someone to kick me in the balls.  At least that paid would go away eventually.To be fair, I'm only whining because I love what this game could've been.  Wasting that much potential should be a crime.  The finished, patched version would have been one of the best 4x games of all time.  Unfortunately this game was abandoned to begin development on a sequel that will be turn-based, not real time, and therefore more of a completely different game than a sequel.  While I love turn-based strategy, the RTS version of this game is the one I wanted and now I will never be able to play a polished version of it.  As such, I simply can not recommend it.

												I waited long to write this review as this game had huge potential. It is amazing work considering that it was all made by just one person. number of helpful: 130 of 143 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												A fun, aesthetically pleasing space strategy game that is simply awesome!Or atleast it would be if crucial game elements were fixed.As it stands, 02-02-2014, several game features are severely lacking in polish and there are some design flaws that really jump out - such as any unmonitored battle being auto-calculated without taking into calculation such things as ship armour or shields, etc. which essentially makes the elaborate, fully customizable ship designing pretty much redundant.Or the way that the AI can win the game without warning due to building a late-game Wonder-style building, which you recieve no notification of until it is already built and the game has ended with your defeat (though this building can be disabled by modding. But it's supposed to be a feature-complete, finished game, right?).The game still do not feature alterable gameplay options, leaving you with only the options of adjusting video and audio.The game's features such as customizing races are great, and the shipyard ship-designing is really fun - but if it doesn't matter in the slightest, it isn't really that much of a draw, is it?I don't really think that I can recommend this game as it is at this stage. It has a lot of really cool stuff going for it, but when crucial elements of the game remains broken, that's really just bad. When (hopefully) they have been fixed or have become toggable (as indeed some of the problems seem to stem from the developer's design decisions), the game is definitely something to recommend.But not in its current stage.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												This game was a dream. A fine product in the making with aspirations for greatness. We, the ones who bought in early in development, had further dreams of playing this complex and (even in early stages) fun game.Then it started. Features began to be stripped off the list due to engine limitations (I might add that other early access games have successfully carried out full-engine ports when the limitations of the initial engine became apparent and at no additional expense to the existing financial backers...). The dreams and promises slowly turned to ash in our mouths as this unfinished and limited product got promoted out of beta (some having suggested just in time for sales to boast visibility...).I gave up on this product completely. I wouldn't have thought about it again had I not accidentally clicked into it's forum (I was aiming for Starbound). "What do you want from Star Drive 2?"In summary this product is a promise. It is a shadow of what it could have been and it is well-and-truly abandoned; as even IF the developers take the time to add an additional patch simply to avoid it being permanently labeled 'abandonware' my confidence in the devs doing anything to address any additional bugs (least of all those that are likely to be added into the game by a half-arsed, smoke-and-mirrors patch) is nil.A grave disappointment all round and I truly wish the best for any whom buy into this product (or other products) as I feel burned by this developer and wouldn't wish that upon them.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Forgoing all my past issues with the game, I'm going to focus on one specific feature that is missing.Ingame, deletable, saves. The code for such is already in the game, with one being able to delete custom ship designs, but you can't delete your saves.And depending on how much you play, the space taken up by the saves can get rather large. And given that you have to do through a, by default, hidden folder to reach the saves directory then not everyone is going to know how to manually delete them.I've wiped my saves folder a few times. The first was after Pre-Warp mode was released. I wiped three gigs of save files. The next was after I decided to start using Tech Level Mod, and I wiped 2 gigs worth of save files. Eventually, I wiped those saves out as well clearing out roughly 3 gigs of space. I wiped my save folder again recently, hadn't done it for a long time, and got rid of 6.3 gigs worth of saves. Counting all these saves, I had roughly 14.5 gigs worth.That's practically the size of a completely new game. And if I didn't know how to reach the saves folder, I'd have never thought about cleaning the folder out because well... how large can something as simple as save files get?Given how much space you can eventually rack up in saves, it's rather sad that Stardrive doesn't include a easier way to get rid of them.

number of helpful: 51 of 55 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												I's a 4x made as a real time strategy game. Although you can pause and set the speed to 4x normal (although it would be nice if it could go even faster).The UI stinks. You can't control planetary production or spies as a whole, in groups, auto-repeating, etc. It becomes very grindy just setting up production clicking to add, next planet, click to add, next planet, etc. There's way too much of that crap.The game crashes in longer games. The game doesn't handle too many ships very well. It should really have a unit cap or something but it doesn't and so you can build too many units and mess up your gameplay.There's no multiplayer.The AI interaction sucks. There's not much you can get the AI to do. You can't really coordinate anything with them. It is a shame since 4x games are fun to play cat and mouse with the npcs and pit them at war with each other. Also when you get someone to join your alliance they become part of your race or whatever and they vanish out of existence and you just control all of their units. This also reduces the amount of AI interaction because everyone either joins with someone you don't like or with you and then it's just a 1 v 1. There's a lot of other reasons why this game fails. I have to admit...it is a great genre and the real time space fights especially since you get to custom build them (although it's not as good as it could be but that's another issue) are really fun to watch...but in the end, there are just a waterfall of shortcomings that make this game something nobody will remember.Get it if it is super cheap like a few bucks and you like 4x and RTS. There aren't many RTS crossed with 4X so it's still nice to play for a bit.

												developer abaondoned this to anounce stardrive 2 without ever finishing many of the in game functions and content. my system could start the game, but many of my friends could not even get it to start. their posts in the dev forums went as problem solved. there is a huge memory problem that causes a crash even on my system after a couple hours of play. many crybaby ideas in forums turned most of the game content into nurfs instead of real balancing. the playable races only a few had full ship trees while the rest were place holders. developer money grab attitude has given me the policy to not support indie projects. rather have a company take control of the project and hold people accountable for my dollars.all that out of the way the game even in its unfished form was extremely fun. if you can actually get it to run and play up to the 4 hour limit on single game then stardrive is gonna be a good time. ship customization is unparalleled. and if you can get over the fact that the other races are not and will not ever be finished then who cares. if you can look pass numerous dead ends in the games ui or story function because this project was abandoned for stardrive 2... then you gonna have a good time. for 30 bucks i wouldnt do it theres other fun out there for that kind of money. if it goes on sale id say pick it up. steams good like that.i ultimately would not recommend supporting a game that gets abandoned for a sequel. if track records go this way then i would lookout for anything in the future with names attached to it from members of this project. early access never again.

												This game showed promise. It really could have been a fantastic game, yet the problems with the final product force me to not recommend it.Why?A game match cannot be completed reasonably. Towards the end game there are huge framerate issues/lag that literally bring all ship movement to a near halt . Lots of good gameplay aspects, unfortunately the game is unfinished. Quests are incomplete, ship models are not implemented for some races(The wolf race), and the developer has no intention of finishing/fixing it. What boggles my mind is the developers decision to make a sequel. How could anyone reasonably expect the sequel to be any more of a complete product than this ?I cannot reccomend this game as it was personally dissapointing for me, the developer is incompetent/Shady ,and this is not a finished product.Don't waste your money.

number of helpful: 36 of 38 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												I played this promising game when it was still on Early Access. At the time, it was a very good looking EA full of potential. Artwork was pretty awesome and in the line of Master of Orion and the 4X real-time game concept was pretty interesting (MOO meets Sins of a Solar Empire?). Ship customisation was nearly as in-depth as Galactic Empires V (less techs/weapons, but firing angles matter) and loads of good ideas were there in the making. UI was a bit awkward, but still functional once you had a grip on it and it did not seem impossible to improve.Nearly 3 years later I decided to see how it evolved. Well, it did not. At all.I read the negative reviews and I understood why. The dev went to make the sequel Stardrive 2 instead of delivering a good product. Apparently, that sequel is even more ambitious (yet reuse most of the Artwork) but also even more flawed, unpolished and unfinished). Basically he repeated the same pattern.It is very sad this Zerosum had 2 golden chickens in his hands and instead of collecting eggs over decades, he chose to break their necks and eat them immediately. That is pretty unwise in my opinion, but whatever floats his spaceship... still, I didn't buy Stardrive 2 and may never do.

												Had a Fun time with this game in early access, but the game was never finished. the developer never got around to putting all the features he promised in, now you cant really play it without mods.I will say the ship design and combat is amazing. but designing a ship takes forever, and sometimes you dont even get to make the biggest baddest ships available, becuase the AI got them first and decides your weak enough to just be rolled over. So the diplomacy doesnt work, AI's that want to be friends are weak like you, and others that cvan help with fight for awhile, then sue for peace when things get rough. I had faith in you Zero, but your let me down. I wish you luck tho, you had a great idea here. too bad it wont get finished.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												(6/10) (Turn based 4x fans)(8/10) (Real time strategy fans)Could have been an amazing turn based game, instead the dive into real time gameplay had some innovation potential but overall served to just bring the overall game down for me, removing the thoughtful nature of play that I am after with 4x games.  Instead of carefully planning each turn and building each world, you are constantly under the gun to move as fast as possible and blaze through reflexively.  Its a shame because otherwise the style and production of the game is quite high and would have more than carried it for me for a long while. (Admittedly, I really do not like RTS play to begin with, and my main score reflects coming into the game expecting it to have been a turn based 4x title along genre norms.  The second score applies for people who do prefer the more highly energetic RTS style gameplay over turn based strategy)

												After 140+ hours. I would say: not recommended. While the combat is addictive (building ships and watching them fight in real time) there are just too many bugs/neglects on the developer's part.it has been 9 months, and instead of polishing/fixing the glaring problems, the developer decided ran off to make a sequel instead (read their forums about it)All in all, it does not live up to the dev's promises and comparisons made to galactic civilization or master of orion back in feburary.  it might be worth it if its a steam sale under 5 dollars.Edit: make no mistake, the combat is fun. its just not what was advertised. number of helpful: 32 of 38 people (84%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I'm a pretty big fan of space games in general, and the idea of StarDrive caught my attention. Wow, a real-time 4X game? Sounds great!...It's terrible!I don't like to have to say this about a game that I put money into, but it has to be said for the good of humanity / the steam community. But why such a harsh approach?1. The interface lacks any polish. It's bad, everything is hard to manage. You will feel the pain once you are 10 minutes into the match as it becomes impossible to manage anything. There is no good notification system and you will probably neglect something important for a good 5 minutes of the game.2. The game isn't finished. Yep, it's broken. There are many bugs left in the game and it is NOT feature complete as it says on the steam page. Yes the game is playable, that does not mean it's done. Many of the features the developer promised never made it into the game, and he is making no effort to fix any of the issues the community has presented. Which brings me to my next point.3. The developer has abandoned the game. He has ditched the project and is now working on StarDrive 2, which is basically StarDrive 1 but actually polished. The developer has even gone to the extent to delete all threads which criticize the game. So now everything on the community page looks positive and isn't showing the truth about the game. Luckily he can't delete steam reviews, so I have one last hope to convince you the reader to save your money for a better game.4. The game is just over-priced! I mean really. There are so many better games for half the price or even less. It's not even worth the money. Please buy a real game. The developer himself said this was his 'experiment'.

												I've returned to this game just to check it out to see if it has improved any since release.  I'm sad to say that it doesn't seem like it's had much more care/thought put into it.  It has one of the worst interfaces I've seen in a strategy game which at the very offset of a new game, ruins the entire experience.  Even the tutorial videos aren't done very well as the music eventually overtakes the speaker!  The entire project seems more like an abandonded Frankenstein than a thought-out game.  Additionally, taking a quick tour of the forums tells that the developer is already working on a sequel!?  My advice to the developer is to hire someone who is good with interfaces and the other various front-end facing pieces of the project.  If you're too proud to do that then at least try to play your own game from the perspective of a new player so that you can maybe not make the same mistakes on the next one... :/

number of helpful: 28 of 34 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Although my favourite genre is Space 4X I only played Stardrive recently despite tracking the game throughout.Compared to games such as Distant Worlds Universe I did not find Stardrive immersive at all as it was very uneventful with a limited storyline.  The AI was weak and it very quickly became an AI curbstomp in my first game while still learning the mechanics.  The game is strategically shallow.  There is an obvious need to spam troops.  A good technology tree is essential and this game was distinctly lacking in that respect.  The ground invasion mechanic is very simplistic.The ship design is cool.  The combat is okay but I vastly prefer Sins of a Solar Empire.  I didn't really notice any of the bugs and missing features that some people go on about but then for $8 my expectations were low.The Developer takes an extremely hard line to Moderation which is often unfair and unreasonable.  I've recently seen a poster banned and all his posts deleted despite the fact not a single forum rule was broken.  Some of my posts have also been deleted despite also never breaking a forum rule.  Unfortunately the Developer is stuck in the habit of shooting himself in the foot with respect to the future of his own community. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVC/discussions/0/I really don't understand why some consider the game groundbreaking. I would rate Distant Worlds Universe, Endless Space, Galactic Civilisation 2 and Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion all as significantly better games, each in their own way.  You can see the potential but a lot is unrealised.  There are patches but they are very slow and limited compared to games like Distant Worlds Universe.There is hope with the Stardrive Extended Mod and perhaps there will be a vastly improved effort with Stardrive 2.   It's possible I could really get into them so I'll stay involved.Post Review Note: Along with others I have now been banned and all my posts deleted despite breaking no forum rules. Be warned.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Was a promising game, got it cheap so I didn't care, but I advertised it with some friends and I feel bad right now. I virtually shelved it in my library and waited patiently for good updates to come but they never did, and the game was released unfinished, development was stopped and the dev got away with all the money. Now he's making a 'sequel' which I know I won't be buying unless the recommendation ratings are 90% and above, which is unlikely. A lot of promised features are not present, even some existing features are not fully completed. The game runs bad on my rig after a long session. Visuals are good, but that's about it. Browsing the forums and checking it out again recently, it seems that modders are still trying to make the game work, which is nice, but I still wouldn't recommend it to newcomers.Thank god I still have GalCiv 2 and GalCiv 3 soonI don't blame the Early Access model, it's there for games like Kerbal Space Program, in which I would lose approx. 1000 hours of fun if it the model hadn't existed. For games like Minecraft, Starbound, Arma 3, GalCiv 3, etcIn the future I would be more careful about buying early access games unless the ratings are 90% Positive and above, and the game is already feature complete, Thanks Enhanced Steam for that extra data! ratings right now are 48% positive 52% negative, bad.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												This game is one of those without fully realized potential. I haven't even been able to load the game in months, it just crashes.When it works the game plays beautifully and it's everything I wanted a space brawler to be. But persistent problems with stupid AI, rampant memory leaks, random crashes, and other bugs make this game nearly unplayable without community mods. Unfortunately installing the best community mods often introduces yet more crashes.I would not recommend buying this game, nor will I ever support this developer. As soon as he had his money he stopped what little patching he did and ran off to develop his next game. I get that it's exciting to work on new projects, but it's also important to keep the loyalty of your original fan base.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												Hello fellow gamers.When i first saw Stardrive i thought that this will be very cool, a little different 4X game.At the very first glance we got everything:- Sci Fi theme- Space battles- Development of our Empire- Ship designThe formula for most 4X games is simple. We explore, expand, exploit and exterminate. Easy right? Most 4X games are turn based- but not a Stardrive. It is real time.When i firstly heard of it i thought "cool! it will have more dynamics"Boy.... i was so wrong.StarDrive is semi finished game.I know- hundreds of gamers wrote it in their reviews. But i don't mean bugs, no update for.... ever.I meen there are only few techs, some about 5-7 buildings to go on planets, few ships.And thats not all!The galactic is very empty space- sure there are some pirates and aliens but this is about it.Nothing more.So what we really get from buying this game?Pretty decent ship design tool.O! and the treading cards.....Well music is nice but there is no additional soundtrack so we actually have to play this game to listen to it......And the dynamic of play i was thinking about?Nope. This game is slower than most of the turn baset games.So....Plus:+ very good alien graphics+ space looks nice+ music+ ship designer+ space battles are niceMinus:- well you bought a demo of beta version of game- bugs- no joy- slooooooooowwwwwww and boring- where is content  ????I'm big fan of SciFi and i adore 4X genre and i have to say:Don't buy it. Please. DON'T

number of helpful: 24 of 30 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												This game tried so hard to be MoO2. It feels like the developers tried just a little too hard to differentiate it. "What if we did MoO2 but real time? TOTALLY AWESOME, AMIRITE?"  The most glaring problem is that the sense of time scale is normalized. Ships fight in the same time that planets are colonized. I can understand possibly having ship TRAVEL and colonization on the same scale, but combat is vastly, vastly faster.  However, it's still on the same time scale.The user interface is abysmal. Tooltips aren't really tips. The user icons aren't extremely desciptive, but can be memorized. It's not explained what some of the icons are. It took a few google searches to figure out that the swirlies next to system or planet names means there's an exploration anomaly. Nothing in the game indicated this. It was my third play attempt that I figured this out.  The tooltip time to show is very long, so I'm waiting 15~30s to figure out what that button does.Ship design is nice, but not my cup of tea. I have no idea what gun is better than another.  There are too many variables to balance.This game is definitely not for me. Looking for something that's difficult to learn and master? Perhaps this is for you. To me, this is a nice beta product. Needs s-loads of polish.

number of helpful: 16 of 18 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Despite it initially having amazing potential to be a near-flawless modern equivalent of Moo2 (Master of Orion 2 - the quintessential 4x strategy game from the 90s), the developer has effectively ceased meaningful work on this project.I, like many Steam members, purchased this game during the so-called "beta" stage with the intention of ultimately playing the game in a fully-functional completed state. Unfortunately, this will never happen as the developer (a guy going by the name of "Zero") simply proclaimed the same beta-level product as "final" and proceeded to publicly state that any future progress will be solely at his own personal "whims".At the time of this writing (10/10/13), the game is known to be *extremely* buggy with large swaths of functionality crippled or non-existant. Past promises of additional features go unfullfilled (multiplayer, etc.). Further, anyone with the gall to complain about the situation (however civil they may be) on the developer or Steam forums is promptly banned and any associated content is deleted (I know this because I have similarly been banned from the StarDrive Steam forums). NOTE: My specific offense... The action that immediately prompted my banning... was that I noticed that a particular thread which was critical of StarDrive was deleted and so I asked why. I suspect that the aggressive action being taken against anyone who complains is a result of the game currently being on-sale, advertised on the Steam main page as a "daily deal" (Zero surely wouldn't want customers' 100% valid concerns & complaints to negatively affect sales of this very dead project).Check the StarDrive forums on Steam for yourself and you will certainly come across content from angry customers who (rightly) feel cheated - that is, if you get to it before said posts are deleted. As I write this, StarDrive is being advertised & sold on Steam's front page. I sincerely pity anyone unfortunate enough to purchase this steaming pile only to inevitably find out how they've been robbed.What's most offensive (aside from the literal theft which is being perpetrated - that is, the game being advertised as beyond beta and fully functional), is the *EXTREME* arrogance displayed by the developer. Observe a snippet from a forum post on the official StarDrive website (before it was deleted):"Zero: I'll be as clear as I can be... I think StarDrive vanilla is a fine game. I'm happy with it. I'll be patching it here and there as my whims take me. If you feel cheated by StarDrive, kindly scroll up to the upper right portion of your browser screen and click the "Logout" button. I don't want to hear it."There you have it, directly from the horse's (Zero's) mouth. The game, in its currently crippled and bug-riddled state will only be worked on if Zero's "whims" allow. Further, if you purchase the game only to find out that it's unplayable in many ways, don't bother complaining because he absolutely does not care (after all, he already has your money).Would *you* knowingly purchase something from a person or company which displays such a low opinion of the customer's (absolutely valid) concerns? I didn't think so. Neither would I. Do not support this developer. Such behavior in business should absolutely not be rewarded.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!!Update (10/11/13): Immediately following the end of the StarDrive front-page sale on Steam, I found myself no longer banned on the forums. While I guess it's a "good" thing that I'm no longer banned, it speaks quite loudly for the theory that the recent aggressive ban-hammer usage was indeed due to the developer not wanting negative forum posts to affect sales (regardless of their validity). In addition, the forums are back to being predominantly full of complaints where as yesterday such threads were being deleted as fast as they could be posted.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												It pains me to admit but I don't recommend this game.I'm coming up 100 played on this game and I will probably play more as personally I enjoy playing StarDrive but I can not in good conscience recommend buy this title to even my vile enemies. Unless its on Sale, then it may be worth it if you enjoy this type of game. If I we're you however, right now considering buy StarDrive, I would spend my money of Galactic Civilation 3. It's the same game has this, in fact I would say this game is a bad copy of Gal Civ 2 which is a 'banging' game, although not as graphically nice as StarDrive gameplay is so much better. So if you can afford it Gal Civ 3. if you want to save money gal civ 2. Anything but StarDrive.Right, so I've had a rant but objectively what wrong with the game. Weirdly not alot. It crashes for time to time normally because I'm tabbing out but autosaves stops that from been a big issue, and few minute roll back max is not really anything to get worked up over. The AI is bad, there are times that it seems slow and dumb, not even able to get off the starting planet. Other time as soon as they make contact they declare war and within 5 mins I have two invasion fleets heading to two different systems, this with the first 20mins of the game. I suppose you could agrue a degree of dynamic realism with the AI but it doesn't feel like that it just seems break. Hypo active somethings and hyper active other times never a good balance. The Gameplay is very long but that not really a fault of the game, more the genre. The tech tree is a bit bland as it's a standard tech tree discuss what race you play has.In final conclusion; I enjoy playing the game, it has some nice features to it and a good about of variety when it come to ship design and weapons. However the game feels unfinished whenever I play Stardrive I have fun but i'm not satified and its for that reason I can't recommend it.

number of helpful: 19 of 24 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Well, I bought StarDrive while it was still in Beta and promised a paradise of gameplay. I love simulation games especially if they provide a scenery like StarDrive: The space. Bought the beta, played the beta, loved the beta. I got about 20 hrs gameplay of which about 18 are from the beta. It's not much I know but after 18 hrs of beta it got kinda boring and was too much frickling and tuning of the fleets. I hoped I get a Spacesimulation where you can prosper by trade, being completly neutral and just prosper. I was totally wrong:Beta provided the player with one gamemode: Sandbox   -  It's a beta, I can live with that.Release versions increased the number of gamemodes by 0! - Still Sandbox   (You have to massacre all AI's to end the game, even those you established a peace treaty with)Beta provided animated Cutscenes   -   Release doesn't even show me a picture anymore (There are actually Issues with the animation but I'd love to get at least a nice Picture of the race I'm talking to. For my eyes sake...)I could go on and on but to summarize:beta - pretty good for a betarelease - holy shmoly! Did the game degenerate into "Pre-release alpha somewhat not existent development state"?It's very sad StarDrive evolved in something I would call a Beta-Heist. Throw a good beta (I really aprreciate the effort of the developer), cash in and relax. And the update released got a timespan of about: "What? What game is updating? StarDrive? Whats that?". Actually happened to me last update and happened to me when I missclicked the game in Steam. That's the reason why I'm writing this review now: played it, got bored after 20 minutes ingame.For me it's a game I will play time to time (I think 20 minutes max) and keep it as a reminder: Never trust a pre-release.Until the game is fixed and the developers find their love to the game they developed: I do NOT and will NOT recommend this game. Period.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Do not buy Stardrive. This game is an unfinished product. It is, at best, “glitchy”. It's an “early access” with no chance of being fixed. Apparently, for reasons beyond the developer, he isn't allowed to work on the engine of the game any more, or something.This is rather sad because the game needs optimization, badly. The controls and interface of the game aren't adequate. It makes an obtuse game with a steep learning curve even more convoluted. Basic RTS controls, like finding idle workers or rally points aren't implemented. At least one technology in the science tree doesn't work as described. Ships, especially freighters, lack a good path-finding, making them delay deliveries of vital goods, but it happens to offensive fleets too. Trading technologies requires you look up, -or know the cost by heart-, of everything in the science tree or risk the ire of the IA. The planet managing screen lacks clarity and the possibility for quick changes. The ship building interface refuses to show critical information, like the rate of fire, the global ammunition consumption per second or the global energy consumption. While it can be nice to figure out this puzzle, you have to recalculate everything as soon as you improve your design with new technologies. Having to look up the wiki for vital weapon-data is also unforgivable for a game that requires such precision in its main mechanic from the player. Personalising larger ship becomes a tedious chore.Speaking of ship building, while it is nice to modify them depending on your style, it doesn't take into account how the game works as a whole. The IA isn't a big threat later on in the game as much as it is in the beginning, and that can be circumvented as soon as you realise what variable the computer uses for it's moves: the size of your fleet. Just build a big fleet, and you've won. You don't even need to research, or spend hours personalising cruisers. In the end, it is completely pointless, because you will already be winning by the time you get to bigger spacecrafts, making their puzzle-like personalisation moot and time wasting.Worse, this system isn't as open as it pretends to be: you cannot build viable ships if you deviate from a certain type of fighter. If you are thinking of building a huge flying fortresses which shoots at everything in all directions, think again: one ship attacks one ship. Sure, the area of effect damage might hit others too, but that's leaving it up to chance, or worse, the IA. The attacks your ships employ are always the same: charge! There is an option to turn on a “broadside” tactic but it doesn't work according to the forums. When you get right down to it, the changes you make to your ships are quantitative, not qualitative. You decide the weapons and the defences, and how much of each, and then try to figure out the best way to power the whole thing and keep sufficient ammunition. In essence, this more open system is just more complex than the one in Endless Space, replacing the straightforwardness of it with inconvenient and pointless creation tools. Also, Endless Space has more tactics during the combat phases, with three different phases, defining tactics for each, heroes and hero abilities. In Endless Space, the ships are not just flying towards each other like a Middle Age jousting competition.It's a shame since Stardrive sounds good on paper. A better IA and path-finding across the board would have gone a long way. An IA that changes tactics depending on difficulty, rather than giving it a boring bonus to resources to compensate for it's inadequacies, would also give a more organic and challenging experience. Being able to annexe other civilizations peacefully by building a federation is great but removes diversity from the game world, by having the player taking control over the planets and fleets of the ally, making end game seem even more without challenge when you suddenly control half the map. Finally, on a positive note, the aesthetic of the game, the design of the races and the ships, are very pleasing and enjoyable even thought there are basically references to other media (like the Wing Commander series, the mythos of Cthulhu, the Asari from Mass Effect, etc.). The mixture of all the references kind of creates its own style. The rest of the game though needed a lot more polish.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												I have played many 4X games, all of Master of Orion series, Endless Space and few others, so StarDrive was a must test. I liked the videos and screenshots, but actually playing it did not deliver. 15 minutes was all i could stand. The controls and UI are simply horrible. Buttons are small and spread wide across the screen borders. Font is plain and tiny, you can't scale them up. All the info is big masses of this tiny text, from which you need to gather information of what's happening, what means what. At the point i was simply trying to move camera around the galaxy, i quickly noted the developer hasn't learned anything about mouse controls from other games. Most of the general mouse functionality, such as simply dragging would have made it much better. Does he expect me to use arrow keys to navigate the map? But it was time to quit game before actually seeing any space combat, shame.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Do not buy this game expecting any 4x4 action within the first 15 or so hours. Painful to say the least. no tutorials worth a damn and the control scheme is out of the early 90's. My bad buy of the 2014 Jan sale and I'm really dissapointed, Such potential there but no flesh at all. It appeared when I bought this that it was early access but it now seems to be "Full Release" a few days after the steam sale. A real shame as this could have been my space total war. A decent blow by blow tutorial would probably help to "fix" the game for most. I am a 4x4 vet and still couldn't figure out why they made WSAD the "ship control" that you barely use instead of the "map movement" like any other 4x4 nowadays. This was suposedly a beta when I bought it but in the last few days has been registered complete. I would love to see this come good with a few simple additions to early gameplay (tutorial (that isn't just screen grabs) anyone). I won't be asking for a refund but I really do ask for a developer tutorial, and ask for the dev's to not rely on community love for them to do your job for you. Valve should also take note, one more game delivered as finished when still in alpha. Where's the QA?this isn't a hate message, I wan't this game to succeed but I also want it to be great, dev's, you now got the cash, finish the game please.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												I bought this game months ago and have played it after each patch release.  To date after 63 hours of play.... I still find it unplayable.   Those 63 hours compose many games that started off with promise but died out for one bug, balance issue, unfinished feature or another.  The core game shows great promise, but with debilitating bugs, and unfinshed content.I had been waiting to write a reveiw though as patches were still coming and I was holding out hope.  Now the developer anounced they are done with this game and are working on a sequel.  The sequel will include all the things promised in the original game, I only need to pay again...  They did promise a 33% discount to current stardrive owners but that just feels like I have to pay 66% more for the game I tried to buy the first time.So in summary BUYER beware of Stardrive and it's developer.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												(Feb 2015)The game did have a lot of potential and was fun to play while it lasted. End game crashing issues, end game becomes a resource hog, which making it impossible to finish and destroys any desire to finish the game. The game is also very unfinished and only some of the features promised.  Now the developer is making a second game. Which I will not be buying because if someone can not make good on his word with the first game, why would he do it for the second game. The second game may be better, but I bet he will employ many of the same tactics as he did with the first. Do not buy the second game if it goes early access, wait until the game comes out and is reviewed before making a purchase.(Oct 2016)Just to update anyone who may be interested in this game. As mentioned above, my verdict still stands. The game was completely abandoned and has many glary late game bugs that will give you an anuerysm just to want to complete it. I have also been following stardrive II. If you go to the forums and read reviews, the developer appears to be is treating the 2nd game as the first. The only added difference is now there is DLC, not borthering to fix the bugs already in the game, and is more concerned about earning money then improving and making a worthwhile 4x game that is fun to play and has great depth. There are many other options to choose from to have a good 4x experience. A great example would be stellaris, which is more of a grand strategy in space.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Not a bad concept as this game is quite different than traditional 4x games, but honestly this game just feels too "small" to be anything other than a bargin bin, $5 time waster.  Here's why:1) You can discover the entire galaxy with literally your first scout ship with almost no impunity.  No need to develop a drive or anything.  2) You can seemingly spend your time waiting on research building way points that connect virtually everywhere (seemingly no drawbacks or economic penalty for doing this).3) Economy is ENTIRELY population based.  Expanding your empire's economy relies on you NOT building any actual buildings (at least early).  Maintenance costs on buildings that are designed to increase food, defenses, or production ALL drain more out of your income than actual ships, so it's better to just colonize and send colonists and food to the planets for seemingly forever till they have enough people to grow.  Just a bizarre concept that doesn't feel rational to me, there really is no option to have a small, but robust empire. It's zerg expansion or die.  4) Conquering enemies, likewise, involves nothing more than zerg tactics (i.e. spamming smallers missle ships and troops).  All you have to do is land more troops on the planet than the enemy has and it's soon yours, you can actaully do that by flying right past their defense fleet and zerg landing while a small number of attacks ships keeps their fleet busy.  Very silly strat but works easily.5) Diplomacy is haywire. People either love you to death regardless of your actions or they want to murder you out right.  Then they simply want to join with you or your enemy, effectively taking the diversity out of the galaxy and matching one big against another big.  Really saps the interest in the game.  6) Ship design is convoluted and seemingly pointless.  You don't know what you need to put and where and there is no manual whatsoever to figure it out.  Simply putting a power source on a ship isn't enough, you need to add wiring that connects the guns or the shields or the bridge to that power source....at the expense of things like armor.  It's like a really terrible game of minesweep to be honest and I like complexity in games, I play 4x games and Paradox games like EU, CK2, and Hearts of Iron....but this ship design leaves me baffled.All in all, this just feels like a very incomplete game that could have been much better if things like the economy and diplomacy had been fleshed out.  The battle system is fun to an extent, but it boils down to zerg tactics.  Bring enough cheap to produce missle frigates and focus fire for the win, leave the tactics at home.  I can't recommend this game.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Played this game in Beta and was really excited.  4X space rts with potential to be best of the era.Gameplay is deep without being confusing or overbearing.Unfortunately, the game is unfinished.  When Alpha was released I immediately purchased as it was sold with the promise of remaining content being added.Unless you're running this game on D-Wave One (google it) this game WILL be slow by the times you reach a good point in the tech tree.My PC is still pretty high spec and struggles to run it on anything past 1280x1024 resolution.The game is also littered with bugs, crashes frequently, and doesn't scale to monitor size properly.Would love to recommend this game if it was finished as it is such a good idea, and such a great presentation, but at the moment all I can say is I want a refund.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												This game has so much ambition, but falls flat on it's face in execution. You literally cannot play this game without some sort of AI mode, and the interface feels extremely dated compared to how modern games are controlled. It has a bunch of grand ideas, but with no easy way to execute them it just feels pointless. To put it simply, this game left Greenlight way too early, and should still be in Early Access.The Dimplomacy portrats are really cool, I'll admit. If only I can see more than the bottom half of them (fun fact a Microsoft .NET Frakework 4 update broke the portrats last week parenthesis laugh)I cannot reccomend this game now, but maybe, someday...

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Here we are, months after purchase and hours into the game.So much potential, squandered, wasted.ZeroSum games was basically a one-man studio, with what seemed like a desire to bring back a great space-4X in the vein of games like Masters of Orion.  Oh, the disappointment.It started great.  Bought this on early access, it had some problems, a couple major ones in fact, but it was close enough that you could see the point of it all, even then, and could see the few hops and leaps it'd take to get the foundations in place and really start cranking out an awesome game.Instead, what we got were sweet nothings and empty promises from ZeroSum, tales of how we would get X Y and Z features or fixes.  Trade is still broken, warping still doesn't work properly, warp nodes and defensive emplacements are still prohibitively expensive, the AI is still crap and consistently allows itself to get rolled over in stupid and meaningless ways, often outright killing themselves due to what should be only one or two MINOR circumstances regarding their worlds and infrastructure...  No balance, no design, no polish, the damn game isn't even finished.ZeroSum took a game, created a clear image, started tapping serious potential...  And then turned around and flipped their entire customer-base for this game the bird.  Zero literally said he would fix the problems and get the game working...  After saying this, he never even got around to the first major gameplay problem, the broken Freighters...  And then announced StarDrive 2.Do not buy this game, do not support ZeroSum games, do not support Iceberg Interactive until they drop ZeroSum, because at the very least, ZeroSum Games is nothing more than a shady, cash-grab studio who does not deserve to be called a Games Developer, and Iceberg deserves to same insults and utter lack of respect for as long as they intend on keeping such a disingenuous, malicious individual/studio under their umbrella.StarDrive is a game to AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Would recommend to anyone thinking about purchasing this game to bypass the official forums as they are seriously biased to deleting anything relating to major complaints about the game. Click on the find community groups and take a look at stardrive continued. I bought the game code off Amazon after the supposed "release" date. I assumed I was getting a completed game. Wrong. Not in any way worth 29.99. The game, as IGN reviewed it, feels like "a big black hole". A game or two and you'll realize all games feel the same. I know there are supporters of this game, but all the negative reviews kind of speak for themselves. Hey, if it walks like a duck and talks like a duck.........I have no need to notate the issues with the game because everything is pretty much well documented in previous posts. Buy if you want, or don't. Matters not to me. Just trying to help people save money. I happened to call Amazon right before Zero had all the negative threads deleted and asked them to look at the forums. I got a refund of my 29.99 because of it. Now that I've finally posted a thumbs down I wash my hands of anything from this developer.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Warning - this is longI found Stardrive ages ago and saw a lot of good things about it.  It was in alpha/beta though and Steam was nice enough to point me at the products webpage, because as handy as steam is they cant list all of a products features on their little webpage (I dont think it had the read more tabs at the time).  Looking at the developers product page and seeing youtube videos of what you are going to purchase is just good consumer behavior so that you know what you are purchasing.   It looked really interesting and offered things such as Moo2 like but RTS 4xMultiplayerCreate your own fleet designsSpecial Missions in which you assume control of an individual ship instead of a whole sideA sandbox mode with an engaging storyline.Neutral factions like remeneant and piratesA variety of random Galaxy events.Shortly after buying in the developer said he was temporarly removing multiplayer to work out the kinks. Of course the sandbox storymode wasnt finished yet but thats ok it was in beta and we saw how it was going to work with researching technologys and contacting a neutral planet and yadda yadda.  And watching the WTF is, along with other videos I knew what to expect with late game latency, so when people bashed on it I spoke up for it, telling people to give it time.  As a one person developer a 1-2 year wait for him to fix things up was acceptable.  Especialy for a game that had already been in development for something like 4 years.  But it was nearly done,  so we should hold on before making judgements.  I made guides, tried to help people out,and gave suggestions.  But the longer it went on the more sour it got.  A couple weeks out of its -short- Beta when we could no longer get refunds there was a 50% off sale.  A couple months after that we were told Multiplayer would never make it to the game and that maybe in a stardrive 2 we would get it.   Special missions were abandoned all together.  The Galaxy events were restricted to simple planatary shifts for fertility/richness.  The Remenent story-arc was removed (and then later reintroduced in a shoddy manner).  Some of the AI's were just left in a crippeled state.   And then afterall of that there was a Fertility/abundance nerf across all difficultes (that the AI ignores) that you cant disable... Why nerf fertility/abund in a single player game?  A -lot- of players got banned from the message boards for silly things and it was a pretty rage induceing time all around.  But thats ok I thought,  I decided to give him more time.  He said development would 'slow' while stardrive 2 was in development but we could expect improvements.  I decided to wait for SD2 to get finished before looking back and seeing what has changed.So this last week I gave it a try again.  And I have to say i am not very happy with it.  I enjoyed the game more during beta and after 'release' with the late game slowdown then I do now.  Sure some small bugs were fixed with fire arcs and its a little bit smoother.  But several AI's just sit there and let other AI's conquer them with out putting up a fight, several races just refuse diplomacy of any sort (usualy the ones that are conquering other ai's),  and the AI still cheats up the wazzoo building fleets it cant possibly support.  And overall it feels really bad fighting over a 4 population planet with a 1.2 fertility and 1.1 richness because thats the best there is out there.  In the end the game currently (may 2015) feels unfinished (even more so then during beta), and in need of a good AI patch, a balance patch, a few new galaxy option sliders to combat what was done post release, and maybe a gamemode paid DLC.  I'm gratefull for the 33% discount on SD2 for SD1 owners,  its a nice gesture.  And I really do hope SD2 turns out well, and can compete with other games in the turn based strat genre. But in the end this game also made me deicde to hold off on SD2 until its cheep as dirt.. because no matter how good it looks 'now'  it could be a lot worse in 6 months.   And thats just not something I ever really expected to say about a game.  ps- yes I know my spelling sucks. Hopefully it wasnt too bad.

Not because it is terrible as it is, but because I feel like I have been cheated on this one, and paying the dev of this game more money is supporting quitter.I was promised many improvements, patches and possibly multiplayer after launch. When I first time played it and I did succesful empire, my game crashed quite few times when I was too long on planet invasion screen or exited it improperly... is that bug still there? Yes. Back then I even went to trouble of taking the screen shot of the error message and posting it to Stardrive forums in good belief that it´d be fixed, and I went back to that old picture when it happened to me again 3 days ago, and YES! it was same error message, related to ground invasion screen, it is same bug! what a fool I am.And now the dev has ditched this game to make... Surprise surprise, Stardrive 2, with people that made Endless Space. Will I buy that game? Hell No! I will jump on board of Galciv 3 or planetary annihilation, they are most likely out at reasonable price (and reviewed so I know if I should buy them or not) when Stardrive 2 comes out or goes to alpha to beg for money to "finish" it.Dev of this game has lost his credibility to me. He pretty much cheated me 30€ which is ridiculous now that I think I could have bought two or three reasonably priced, well reviewed and recommended indie strategies.In the end, if you want decent single-player space RTS, buy this, but if you even little care what kind of business model or people your money is going to, please dont.Be responsible consumer.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												STARDRIVE.The little 4X that almost could..For starters, i must voice my bias. Towards grand-stategy and 4X-Games. They have been my personal guilty pleasure for the longest time. However, even with the enjoyment i get from them. There are examples of the genre that are not exactly the best and unfortunately StarDrive falls to that category.This is easily explained, the game is dull. Bloody dull...  In all of my 140+ Hours of playing it, i have completed it only thrice.And every time, the end-game played out the same. Every single time, not counting the time i went all Borg with the Opteris. This is mainly due to design issues with the Tech- political- and AI-systems, they feel unfinished and in many ways they still are. The game still crashes now-and-again and some of the mods that have been made for the game only make it even more unstable. (This just might be only on my end, but its still a noteworthy issue.)And for a game that is aesthetically very similiar to the good old Master of Orion series, the problems only make it worse. Since in its core, the game is broken and even with the patching the developer has done (and if memory serves it was just one guy.) the game is still broken.And i'm really sad about it, since the idea is so good. A spiritual successor to Master of Orion, with better graphics, sound and all the other fluff. StarDrive tries to be that game and in some ways it has succeeded, but the technical and design issues are the things that kill the experience, not to mention the pacing.In all, StarDrive is a decent game. Even with all of its obvious problems, it is somewhat enjoyable. But not by much. It gets dull really fast and with the pacing being off, i really doubt that you could squeeze more than few playthroughs out of it. And even the modular ship building system, can only squeeze so much fun out of it.StarDrive.I think a C , is the best grade i can settle for. This coming from the game being still mostly incompleted and the modding only helps so much. But to give a yes or no on the recommendation option, i think i still need to put a yes on it. Since Steam has no "neutral"-option in the recommendation thing..Furthermore, i would not recommend paying full price, buy this when it goes on sale. Since the content isnt there for 30€ (or regional equivelant.).

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												SPANISHEs un juego con buenas ideas y bastante contenido. Aún así, el desarrollador lo ha dejado a medio hacer, y eso se nota mucho. A continuación enumero las las cosas que más me han sacado de quicio:1-No hay tutorial. Hay un hermoso botón donde dice "tutorial" pero se trata tan solo de una pequeña presentación que te muestra lo básico de lo básico. En un juego que se vanagloria de tener tanta profundidad como éste tal cosa no es aceptable.2-El juego tiene amplias opciones de automatización (admistración automática de planetas y flotas, recursos, etc). Sería genial, si no fuera porque no funciona. Deja un planeta en manos de la IA y te lo joderá seguro.3-En las partidas avanzadas, la incesante actividad de flotas y las constantes batallas por todo el mapa ralentizan de forma considerable el juego. No es un problema de mi máquina, pues ha sido documentado por mucha más gente en los foros.4-En mi caso, después de una larga partida de algo más de 10 horas, al día siguiente el juego se niega a funcionar correctamente, congelándose la pantalla cada 4 ó 5 segundos. Por esa razón lo he desinstalado.En conslusión, si lo encuentras barato (menos de 7-8 eur), puedes jugártela y comprarlo si tienes muchas ganas. Pero ten en cuenta que si encuentras algún bug gordo o te molesta alguna de las cosas anteriores, ningún desarrollador lo va a solucionar.CONSEJO: SI ESTÁS BUSCANDO UN JUEGO DE ESTRATEGIA 4X, VE A POR LOS TÍTULOS MÁS CONSOLIDADOS QUE ÉSTE.ENGLISHThe game has a lot of content and features very good ideas, however the developer left it incomplete to work on another project (see Stardrive 2). The fact that this game is unfinished and unpolished is really evident sometimes. Let me show you the 4 things that angry me the most:1-No tutorial. Yeah, there is a big shiny button tagged "Tutorial" in the main menu, but it's just a slideshow that provides little to no useful info. In a game which aims to be so deep and complex, this is a serious issue.2-Automatization. The game let's you give control of various tasks to the AI. Almost anything from planet management to Empire defense can be managed by the machine. Problem is, the AI is stupid.  Give it control of a planet and all the population will be dead in no time.3-The endgame CPU consumption will kill your computer. Although this game is not exactly FarCry 3 graphics wise, the constant battles and endless activity during an advanced game will cause freezing and periodic stuttering. This issue has already been documented in various forums. 4-In my case, after 10 hours of "successful" playing, now the game refuses to even work properly, causing stuttering even when I'm at the main menu and taking about 5 minutes to load. For this reason I uninstalled it.In conclussion: if you really like the concept of this game or feel like playing, buy it if you find it at a good price (less than 8 eur). Keep in mind, however, that this game is already considered "complete" by the developer, and so none of the issues explained above, along with those that you find, are going to be fixed.ADVICE: IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR A 4X GAME, GO FOR THE MORE POLISHED TITLES

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												This game has a lot of promise and potential, but it fails to live up to any of that. number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												What at first seemed like a promising new addition to the 4X genre turned out to be a complete disaster.The game is incomplete and the devs have since jumped ship to rebuild the game from scratch under a separate title, "Stardrive 2". No has been compensated in any way, and this broken, unfinished mess is now being touted as a complete game.As for the specific issues with the game:PROS-1. It is a 4X game played in real time. That allows for a number of new strategies not possible in the ordinarily turn-based genre.2. Stardrive brought something new to the 4X table with the ability to design/fit your ships from scratch. This was the core pulling factor of the game. With customizable ships, you could choose from a pre-existing hull and redesign the ship to suit whatever specialised need. Titanic capital ships dedicated to bombing a planet into a foetid hellhole (i.e. conducting Exterminatus)? Done. Beam cannons on a fighter? No problemo. Or how about a logistics ship to provide repairs to your fleet on the go? All possible.CONS-1. The Sunburn engine is a laggy unoptimized mess. The framerate basically commits suicide during mid to late game, and especially in the middle of large fleet battles involving more than a hundred ships, even more so with the fact that the game runs in real time. The devs took a bad gamble opting to use a new engine with little repute, and lost.2. The AI is shallow at best, and in the state the devs had left the game, you can't do much more than basic threatening, bargaining, and decaring war. Some of the interaction options do not even seem to have any real purpose or effect.3. The game claims to be mod-friendly, however due to the limitations of the engine it can only run 1 mod at any time.4. Planetary interaction with colonies and ground troops could truly be better. Every ground unit across all the playable races are basically just reskins of one another, and the gameplay lacks any sort of strategic depth beyond throwing as many troops as possible at the enemy (or as many as you can fit on the map). Building placement doesn't appear to have any strategic element either.5. Finally, the game devs abandoned the sinking ship while all the passengers were still on board. Didn't say a word. One day they just went *poof*, and no one heard from them again until they began advertising their "new" game.'nuff said.Such a pity, really. This game had so much promise....

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												OK this is getting long so don't buy this game. It's buggy and shallow with few saving graces. After 57 hours of gameplay I can say without a doubt it was not worth the $7.50 I paid for it.I wanted to like this game. It has a lot of things I like but it is too frustrating to play. I spent the first five hours of this game just figuring out how to play, finding a good path up the tech tree, creating an initial build queue and understanding the UI to be decent player. That's was OK because I thought after I had that down things would get better but as time went on it just left me on a plateau and I was no more satisfied than when I first figured out how to play. Things I did enjoy- fitting your own ships with armor, weapons , subsystems and powergrid. Terraforming an ice planet turns it into an ocean planet. The artifacts are a nice touch and assimilation is very useful but comes too late in the tech tree becasue it is not retroactive.My first successful empire was based on the good luck of finding a planet with 5 thought crystals. This gave and immense boost to my research abilities and I was quickly outpacing the computer. So whipped up a good ship design and threw it into production immediately and soon I had a decent size fleet ready to be mobilized on anything and I learned my first combat lesson just as quickly. Projectiles and missiles suck pretty hard in this game and energy beam weapons are way overpowered.Why? Projectiles miss quite often and require ammo to use which means less space on your ship for armor/shield/powergrid mods and require resupply unless you have the painfully slow ammo fabricator. Missiles are slow and are easily avoidable if you maneuver your ships away from them and also require ammo. Beam weapons almost never miss (I had a beam weapon miss a few times when I paused the game and gave an order to attack then unpaused and the computer fired all weapons even though I was facing the opposite direction from my target? Still haven't figured that one out.) and require no ammo so making a good beam boat or two pretty much seals victory every time. Also want to touch on the "phased ordinance" tech here as this tech allows for a 50% chance of projectiles penetrating shields. You can unlock it twice so you can get 100% penetration but the first unlock is waaaay to early in the tree and there is only one other tech cheaper to start. It seems this was done to compensate for the low hit ratio of projectiles but it just breaks the game for shield users way early on. Don't even get me started on projectile armor penetration as well.So I went back and rebuilt my ships with beams and ventured back out this time to steamroll everything in sight and that was pretty fun. After the initial wave of attacks I had reduced my enemies fleet to just freighters and they never seemed to recover. They never built another fleet of any size comparable to the first and this happened every time in every game I played with every race. You have one good fleet fight with the AI and its GG from them.Also found out the hard way to never EVER press escape in the fitting window with the arcs overlay. I thought escape would drop the overlay and put you back to the fitting window while actually it will drop you from the fitting screen entirely without the chance to save your design. I always did the weapon arcs last so I lost a few good designs to an errant key press and I quit the games a few times doing that. The escape key is not consistent in the UI and lead me to believe it was more a "go back" button then a "close window" button.And don't forget completely broken ground combat where if you take over from the AI and move your own guys it will allow your troops to automatically fire on each other as if they were the enemy and you have no way of stopping them until the unit dies!! Grrr!!!
