number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												StarDrive is one of those games that looked good and innovative when it was in development, but ultimately fell short of expectations once it was released. The game was released fairly quickly - some would say a bit too quickly - and while it did receive several significant patches and updates after release, the post-launch development was not nearly as comprehensive as the community, in my opinion, deserved. As of the writing of this review, ZeroSum Games has already announced that they are making a sequel. Maybe it's just the cynic in me, but it seems as though this first game was really little more than a test run designed to iron things out and bilk some folks out of the money that the studio decided they needed to create the 'real' game. I can only hope that this sequel does more to address the issues that StarDrive had and provides a more satisfying 4x experience.Even at the supposed 'end' of its relatively short development cycle, the game still suffers from a number of glitches and bugs, as well as incomplete or poorly-executed gameplay systems. Ships and fleets often suffer from poor pathfinding and an inability to carry out simple orders. Up until the last update, the few 'random events' that made up the in-game 'storyline' were still incomplete or did not work properly. The lack of any sort of scaleable engine technology or range limitations on your ships pretty much allows any player to scout out the entire map in the blink of an eye, destroying any sense of gradual exploration and leaving you susceptible to zerg rushes from any 'warmonger' races you have the misfortune of rolling up a new game map alongside.Planet development, research, and economics are serviceable but pretty bare-bones. The short tech tree is ridiculously easy to blow through with 'standard' pacing, and really needed to be at least 50% larger than what it was; several branches were seriously underdeveloped. Terraforming is almost nonexistent and the greatest variety of planet facilities is in defenses; there are no more than two or three facilities each for farming, industry, and research. The economic system had the potential to be quite intricate with its system of freighters physically transporting goods between planets; however, the limit of only three resources (food, industry, people) and the seeming lack of promised effects from the economic-related techs don't contribute to a realistic economic model and make it hard to afford much infrastructure.Game setup doesn't provide a lot of options compared to other 4x games (Endless Space, GalCiv 2, and MoO2 - which this game purports to be emulative of - come to mind). Even the largest map size doesn't seem to be quite big enough, particularly given how sparse most star systems are and how many turn out to be crap - which, given the lousy terraforming options, make meaningful expansion of your empire difficult. Locations such as volcanic and ice worlds, gas giants, and asteroid belts, rather than providing additional options, are instead little more than eye candy, contributing nothing of value to the overall game when they could've added whole new dimensions to the tech tree and gameplay. The game's seven races are fairly original, for the most part - conforming to the usual tropes, but distinctive in their own ways, though some are considerably more derivative than others. The diplomatic options are good, if not outstanding, and  the responses provided in the course of shooting the breeze with a particular species are amusing, while providing a gist of each race's personality and culture - though there's not a great deal of background information to be gleaned during the course of gameplay. The diplomacy system gives you an idea of how a given species feels about you, but no feedback on what you can do to improve relations. Espionage provides a number of options for stealing or sabotage in a fairly good, time-duration assignment system that relies on hiring spies and advancing them in rank. I do have to say that the game's ship design system is solid, allowing you to get down into the nitty-gritty of customizing each vessel to the last component. Everything comes down to power; each component has to be within range of a reactor or power conduit or it won't function. Design a ship with too many power-hungry systems but not enough power generators, and systems will shut down once its reserves run dry. Ship-to-ship combat happens in real time on the system maps (a la Sins of a Solar Empire) and hit detection and damage is location-based, with external systems taking damage first before the guts of the ship can be hit. What this means is that ship design must be well thought-out and involves compromise. With only so many slots on a particular hull - and only so many internal and external slots available - you have to strike a balance between power systems, weapons, and defenses. Ships with heavy armor on the outer edges will have less space available for weapons ports; shield generators have limited coverage bubbles and must be positioned to protect the whole ship; reactors are volatile and will cause splash damage to surrounding components if they are destroyed - do you have the space to spare for internal bulkheads, or do you trust your ship's armor and shielding? Each weapon can be given an individual arc, allowing you to construct aggressive, maneuverable, front-heavy gunfighters or well-defended, multi-turreted line warships capable of massive broadsides - or anything in between. All that's needed is a way to lock each weapon in position so it can't be moved - errant clicks while upgrading or changing designs can skew a turret's alignment clear out of whack, which can lead to whole fleets with frakked up aim if you happen to not notice. StarDrive does have some good points and interesting design features, but overall the game feels incomplete. I could go on about other aspects of the game that suffered from clunky design or thin or incomplete treatments, but the message has been stated - StarDrive is not worth picking up, at least not at this point. Clearly it has been popular enough to warrant a sequel, and hopefully the developer will take the time to get things right in the second game. StarDrive 2 definitely needs a far greater level of depth and sophistication in its gameplay if it wants to stand out from its competition in this fairly crowded field of space empire-building games, and needs to have the glitchy systems and underdeveloped features of its predecessor ironed out in order to deliver a satisfying experience. Hopefully the sequel will prove to be a game that greatly improves on its 'trial run' predecessor and is able to succeed because it is well-designed and provides deep gameplay options - something that the original game has not succeeded in delivering.

												I brought this 4x game a while back and was full of promise for what it had the potential to become, back then the developer was promising all sorts of intresting features in the form of updates and frankly they have not turned up in the quanity they should have. Now thats not saying this is a bad game, the ship customization and planet management is excelent and the combat feels like it should in space, but it just can't carry the game on there own. Wheres the Multiplayer? Story mode? Improved diplomacy? We were promised it but it just never materialized. Its a trend thats been happening for the last year with 'pay to play early' Alphas and Betas, and i honestly wouldnt of minded if the game had been continualy updated and polished. But it wasn't, It's AI feels buggy and will uterlly crush you on anything higer than Normal, balancing resource production is a NIGHTMARE, the game crashes after several hours play for no reason and Diplomacy isnt finished, just the classic 'give me tech and planets' approch or picking from a list of things your spys can do. The term 'cash grab' certainly has come to mind.If somebody put another 6 months into polishing and actualy finishing this game it would be great, in its state now? Save your cash, go play Galactic Civilization II, SIns of a Solar Empire or Armada, that should cure your itch for space colonization for awhile.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Game is too easy for classic grand strategy (4X) genre in every aspect. You can learn all the tricks in mere minutes and there's not much to do after that. Most annoying is the tech tree: it is just too shallow and all-visible at start (well, there's something like 1-6 upgrades in 1-3 tech trees in each of five tiers plus one 'hidden' tier). Upgrades are completely evolutional, improving just main characteristic of shield/armor/weapon/etc. Space combat is really nasty too: no matter how much time you spend designing your ships combat result is mostly determined by ability to sustain DPS and hit the target (like a not-so-large pack of cheapest fighters with ammo-less lasers easily destroy something like cruiser). Moreover ships in fleet do not keep formation during combat thus there's no such thing concentrated fire or support ships staying in safe position delivering ammo/repairs to the hot zone. As for diplomacy, well there's none out there. First Civilization had as much diplomatic choices as we have here and it is not the simplicity you want.To be honest there's a couple of things that are good: it is ship designer (however you cannot fit your design with latest weapons/armors just developed by your techs, you need to do it manually) and 'turnless' strategic mode, however there're many space strategies which include these pros and doesn't have so much cons. If you want a good game, go for endless space (easy to learn) or something like space empires V or distant worlds (much harder thingies)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												tl:drThere are no credits anywhere in StarDrive. I'm not surprised. I wouldn't want to put my name to this crap either.And don't buy StarDrive 2 either.I've read a lot of the reviews for this game and they all read much the same, that it was the product of a lone developer who took the money and ran before the game was finished, but not many actually talk about the game beyond "it could have been great!" So to give some insight into what StarDrive is really like:* Path-finding is appalling - Use alt+click to override if you want your ships to get anywhere as fast as possible. There is also such as a thing as too fast. Keep the FTL under 100K unless you want to watch your ships play ping pong around each destination.* Accuracy of weapons that use munitions is appalling - You can either use beam weapons (and suffer appalling lag) or spray the battlefield with ordnance (and suffer appalling lag) to increase the likelihood you'll actually hit anything.* Ground battles are appalling - Have more troops in orbit than there are tiles on the planet, land them all at once and then let the AI take over and forget about it. Do not bother trying to micromanage the ground battle, it is a waste of time and takes too long, so just wait for the notification saying you have taken over the planet.* Manual ship control is appalling - There is no point of reference when you take manual control of a spaceship, the mini-map does not zoom in to help you navigate and the only way to get some idea of which direction you are travelling is to fire forward facing munition weapons and see which way they drift. It is truly horrific trying to fight using manual control, most of the time you'll just be turning on the spot hoping the enemy ships really will fly into your gunsights. That is if you can even get your ship to stop.* The AI is appalling - Nothing can be done about this, although you can abuse it. You can bombard a planet into nothingness and then leave at least one bomber continually dropping nukes because the enemy will continually try to recolonise it until you have wiped them all out of existence. Also, the AI does not send more than four ground troops at once for a ground assault, so just make sure each of your planets has as many hard troops as will fit.* Diplomacy is appalling - Just make sure you buy alliances before someone else gets there first.* The interface is appalling - There is no way to delete save games from within the game. When I did finally find them the first time I did a manual search of the hard dirve they had consumed over 4GB of storage space.* The lag is appalling - By far the worst problem is lag. You won't notice it at first, but the longer a game lasts the worse it gets (and not always because of large numbers of ships). The most impressive lag I've seen is when the final game stats run. I just get the impression it's replaying the game in the background all over again because how else can you make the final game stats lag so atrociously? It's just a map with three bar charts!There is loads more wrong with this game, this is just a shortlist of the ones I can remember, but there must be a reason I pumped 78 hours into this monstrosity? Well, I got it in a bargain bin from an actual shop, so didn't see the reviews initially. But, the main reason I wasted so much time on it is modding. People complain about the crappy tech tree and the cookie-cutter planet development. Then just mod it. Literally everything can be modified. I had whole new branches of technology, new ship hulls (most notably the Borg and a smiley face), new artifacts, new ship modules (from armoured reactors and reactors that were armour, to guns that never ran out of ordnance and armour that was a gun and provided power and never ran out of ordnance), ships that could travel the universe in seconds, new planetary buildings, and so on. Literally everything can be modified, and once you learn how it's not that hard to make a change and then test the effects. Unless you make a mistake, then the game fails to load. Even then, with a little practice, you begin to learn how to read the error message. It is even possible to modify armageddon and have a game that never ends. (Which actually means ends when it crashes.)So given all that potential for making improvement why do I not recommend this game? Because once you start rooting through the game files to make changes you begin to notice strange files and folders that hint at missing features and you begin to understand just how much was left unfinished by the developer and the fact they couldn't even be bothered to remove all of this before releasing the game as a finished product. Like a hint at just how much you are missing out on. But worse than that, even though you've modified every single aspect of the game so you can effortlessly hold off armageddon indefinitely, it only works if you micromanage every single battle because the AI is appalling. I did try imagining my ship commanders were just drunk bullies because they always go after the smallest, weakest enemy ship (fleet orders reset to defaults as soon as you close the fleet setup screen), expertly missing them even though you've modified the Vulcan into a minigun-shotgun with the range and fire power of a sniper rifle, all the while oblivious to the enemy capital ships playing turkey shoot with them, but I couldn't hold that thought for long because it really is a just crap programming and a crap AI. And indefinite ends when the game decides to crash from out of memory (which is impressive when not even a quarter of the 8GB available on this machine is being used) or you just can't stand the lag any longer and know that the lag in the endgame stats is most likely going to crash the game anyway.And then you read the reviews for StarDrive 2 and see the pattern repeating and you realise the developer is never going to learn so long as people continue parting with the cash for unfinished products.Actually, there is one final point to make about this game. I've never before come across a game that didn't have credits somewhere. The credits might run when you complete a game or be hidden somewhere in the menu, but they are always there somewhere. There are no credits anywhere in StarDrive. I'm not surprised. I wouldn't want to put my name to this crap either.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												I'll be up front right now, I like this game. It offers a unique experience and I find myself coming back again and again to play it. That being said I would not recommend it unless it was on at least a 75% sale as the game is not complete and pretty much never will be because the dev dropped it. Now you can play the game, it isn't broken you can play and finish a scenario but this game was abandoned and a lot of promises that were made were broken by the dev so there is lack of content and after a few games you get the gist of how things will go and the prospect of losing goes out the window even on the hardest difficulty. The Blackbox mod can fix this a bit but overall it's a problem. In addition you will suffer a lot late game due to poor optimization that even a really powerful system can't power through. I put a lot of time into this game on my 3570k which was overclocked to 4.8Ghz and on the larger universe settings I still had significant slowdowns and juttering which can and will render the zoomed in direct fleet control unplayable. It basically leads to you sending massed fleets into enemy held systems and hoping that the AI can take care of things. The best thing to do is the leave the universe size to normal and use the Blackbox mod to limit the number of ships the AI can have because if you don't you will quickly find that the AI will continue to pump out droves of ships and each one will make the game run a bit worse after a certain point. That being said if you have a recent Intel based chip(Sandy or newer) your system should easily be able to handle around around a thousand ships in the universe without significant slowdowns.Probably my favorite thing about the game is the ship customization. In a word it's friggin cool and it really makes you feel good when your ship you designed is good enough to take on three or four ships of an equivalent class of ship and come out on top. That is I think the thing that really keeps me coming back because I keep finding better and better ways to build my ships and it feels really engaging.  To wrap up this game had loads of potential but it was let down by poor choices made by the dev in both the way they made the game and how the handled the abandonment of it. It is in no way worth the standard $30 asking price, you can pick it up for the unique experience but only if it's less than $10.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Could be fun, but has a non-existant tutorial. I had no clue how to design my ships, Plus you can't look at pre-made designs to get an idea or upgrade them. It does have a explanation area when you click the question mark, but it really don't explain much, especially about ship design.Their idea of an epic sized galaxy is a joke.All planets are exactly the same size since they all have the exact amount of space to build on.I had trouble with setting up fleets, after a while you get garbage graphics and have to get out of the window to clear them. When adding ships to a fleet, they don't actually move into the fleet area until you move the fleet which makes no sense to me.You have a planet manager, however all you can do in it is to tell the AI what planets to colonize. You can't even use it to move to individual planets. I had to scroll around on the map to find my home planet so I could give build orders.Building anything in this game takes forever. My 3 hours of fame at 4x, all I managed to do is colonize roughly 20 planets and build some facilities and ships. There just doesn't seem like there is a lot of variety of buildings. Oh and you only get to build one of each on each planet. I couldn't find a way to stop time, I just hit random keys until something happened. Eventually I just got borred an quit.I don'tt understand a lot about this game and frankly I don't care, it's got too many issues to be a fun game. I was bored or frustrated most of the time. Glad I got it in a bundle, sure as hell not worth the 30 bucks they're asking for it. Read somewhere that it was abandoned by it's dev for a sequal and that the sequal is just more like an update.Update 7/25/2016: Was so upset about this game that I typoed alot in this review. Fixed all my typos (I think).

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is one of those games with a lot of potential, and also one of those games that never quite lived up to it.The premise is simple. The game takes place on a 2d plane. Your ships can be customized and designed very similar to Gratuitous Space Battles. Any wacky ship design you want, you can build. The game is also highly mod friendly, which is a huge plus in my book.You colonize planets, design ships, build fleets, and conquer the galaxy. Simple enough.Problem is that the game is highly buggy, full of memory leaks and other instabilities. This is a real shame considering how brilliant the game design is. There is just no polish and little to no bug fixing that was done. Be prepared to have your game either slow down to an unplayable crawl and/or crash to desktop continually.Lots of potential but poor execution. Avoid this game unless you like frustration.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is one of those games with a lot of potential, and also one of those games that never quite lived up to it.The premise is simple. The game takes place on a 2d plane. Your ships can be customized and designed very similar to Gratuitous Space Battles. Any wacky ship design you want, you can build. The game is also highly mod friendly, which is a huge plus in my book.You colonize planets, design ships, build fleets, and conquer the galaxy. Simple enough.Problem is that the game is highly buggy, full of memory leaks and other instabilities. This is a real shame considering how brilliant the game design is. There is just no polish and little to no bug fixing that was done. Be prepared to have your game either slow down to an unplayable crawl and/or crash to desktop continually.Lots of potential but poor execution. Avoid this game unless you like frustration.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												StarDrive is an immersive RPG. The amount that goes on in this game after a while starts to get crazy.The concept is simple... zoom in and out with the mouse to view the star systems. The navigation that this game play provides is smooth and allows you to get to which system you need to view. The managing system of seeing all of your empires/planets and being able to allocate production is sophisticated enough but the user interface for it was done simply and made easy to use. Diplomacy can work for or sometimes quickly against you with an opposing empire declaring war. Trade routes, non-aggression pacts, war declaration, and even colony claims can be through diplomacy. Planets come in different varieties such as gas planets, Terran, swamp, barren and a few variants. Be sure to start exploring early and claim good planets, but doing so exposes you to aliens. You will find yourself addicted to this game after a while if you like micro and macro managing planets and a multitude of ships. You are also able to create your own ships (from colony ships to cruisers) and the creation system is a neat one at that. There is also an in game fleet design system that by itself makes the game much more easier to play (and to defend against enemies). Why I support this game even though it has a lag issues (sometimes with and without the mod) is there is a community out there trying to improve this game. Moreover and more importantly for me, you are able to control a SINGLE UNIT and tell them what to fire. You can't say exactly which guns to use, but none the less this is the right idea in my mind to create a new genre : RPG meets first person shooters. Literally, any unit that's out there, choose to control. I wish more games did this in the sense. Imagine playing Starcraft and you can control a marine. Your marine that you are controlling dies so you automatically jump to the next one or go back to the RPG screen. This to me is brilliant and perhaps even game changing in the future. I will have to give it aRATING : 7.0/10Gameplay B- Story / Campaign B- Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music B- Replay-ability B- Overall  C+ (due to lag)Due to lag issues and a need for a mod but either than that I recommend it - especially on sale. Just be extremely wary about the lag issue.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Stardrive is a really good game, though with a few rough edges.  It seems to run fine until late game area where it will lag (on any computer) a good deal.  The develoment is done for it unfortunatly but you can get the blackbox un-official patches from https://bitbucket.org/CrunchyGremlin/sd-idk/overviewBlackbox is still pumping out updates to make the game better and better.  I would have liked to see some multiplayer though or even some more fleshed out storyline (the game has a kind of story you can figure out as you play).The races you meet have very unique looks, especially the space samuri bears.  The ships look and feel amazing and each one can be totally customized and upgraded with research and the shipyard.  With stardrive 2 coming out soon though I might just hold off buying this one and get the sequel (which should have much more added in).All in all I will be buying the sequel, so that should tell you how much I like this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I have been playing this game since its beta release and i think its fair to say this game could have been so much more“Some omissions and flaws, but balanced by excellent alien races and ship design. A welcome addition to the crew.” this says it all nicely but is largely understated. As a whole the management and construction of an empire works quite well but in combination with wonky AI; a civ 5-esque diplomacy screen with reduced options and strange reactions (allies will quickly turn hostile if the wrong trade is proposed); no counterspying option leaves you to get ravaged by enemy spies; many incomplete or just missing features; no multiplayer; and late-game performance issues (I play it on a laptop so it may just be that) the fun factor quickly turns to frustration late in the game.  A lot of features were also just left out, despite being advertised as either implemented or coming soon on the steam store, and will most likely never be implemented as Zero Sum basically dropped everything in development for the game and focused on the production of a sequel, leaving the first game feeling very incompleteBUT there are many aspects that work quite well:The shipyard feature, for example, is amazing. it allows you to arrange unlocked systems on a ship frame so you can create specialized designs (ie resupply, strike, scout, coloyization etc) and allows you to control thier performance levels.too many systems bogs down the power supply, shields over armor can be a vulnurability and more massive means slower travel. to name a few things.the game is visually stunning. you are able to scale the map from a galactic map down to a single star with orbiting planets. the alien races are all fantastically concieved and there are 8 playable races which can be customized to have a number of positive and negative traits upon starting a new game. each race has its own ship designs, and most of them have unique ground unitsI really liked that this game was 4x so that The game flows continuously and allows space battles to occur in real time while the construction and research aspects are turn based progressions. i thought this system worked really well, especially since you can increase the time scaling up to 4x (or more, but not on my laptop) and speed up the slow early stages of the game.Unfortunately the features that i liked did not make up for its short comings, for me at least, and it looks like they will be carried through to the sequel along with countless improvements/features that should have been in this game.VERDICT: this game is not worth $33CAD If this game appeals to you, then I would wait for the sequelIf you've read a fair number of reviews and still want to try it, then wait for a sale to drop the price to $5-10 as there are some mods out there that really add a lot to the game and the game is still enjoyable

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is a one-man-project, and it shows.The One-Man-Show showed itself in a lack of discipline to work on the "boring parts" of a sellable product: rigorous bug-fixing, polishing, usability.A few concepts, such as the design-your-own-ship puzzle are AWESOME. Laying out your own, where to put armour, where the guns. Big engines or small. Truly an inspired idea that made me decide to buy on-the-spot.On the other hand, many parts of the game are buggy, unpolished or even unfinished.For example: The game slows down over time; my campaign has never been not-laggy after the first half hour. This wasn't considered a priority problem, despite multiple people reporting it.Some efforts were made, but it shows there was never enough time for a good fix.All in all: Great concept, but the idea(s) were too big for the one guy implementing them.No more one-man-shows for me, and I'll pass on StarDrive2 as well. ZeroSum games has lost my faith.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												This game involved a lot of really great ideas, all with terrible execution, clunky control, and a UI that makes you want to gougue your eyes out. Ship design in this game might be the deepest ever attempted, but involves far more tedious wiring of power than engineering acumen. You'd almost certainly enjoy Star Ruler's much simpler scheme, which ends up achieving far more creative possibility, or GalCiv and skip the hour-long battleship design process entirely. Automation? Sounds good, but the AI is pretty terrible at minding itself. If you want to get much done, you're forced to take it into your own hands, and deal with the horrid hotkeys, UI, and the rediculous WASD-control of ships, which makes them unavailable for scrolling around the map. You also can't click-drag. You're stuck with arrow keys or zoom-popping like a schizophrenic rabbit. If you want your empire to do its own thing(but also the way you tell it to), play Distant Worlds, because that game has true and almost total automation options that is as capable as the actual enemy AI(which can get rather brutal, unlike stardrive's rather easy bots). Ship combat doesn't even look that good, or play well. If you want something with tactics, go play MOO, and if you want actual cinematic splosion glory, go GalCiv or endless space. Small ships are gross pixel blobs and large ships just tend to look like a bunch of sausages flopping around. There is very little customization available other than the standard race min/maxing before a game starts. Want to slog through a massive galaxy of mostly barren worlds? nope. Want a quick fight between factions already up against each other's shoulders? too bad. Square maps that all play the same. Why not any other game I previously listed, some allowing you to play on 3-d barbell, spherical, or perpedicular galactic arrangements while all allow much more map control. Why was this overlooked?So even if you actually get used to panning around on the arrow keys like a geriatric, navigate your way through obtuse and uninformative UI, and after spending hours plugging your ship's weapons into power sockets, what do you get? Well, you'll be dealing with micromanagement forever. Yep, like Civ5 lategame, but more like all game. Governors are idiots, and basically anything you want to do you're going to have to pause the game and painstakingly order it out so that fleet doesn't fly apart in transit and make sure you pay attention to your ground forces so they don't sit there for days doing nothing!You don't so much play this game as try to bear it. No matter what your tastes, what you really want is something else.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Despite all of the flak this game has received it is still a fun game to play. I missed the Kickstarter for this game but got it as soon as it was available. The game met every expectation I had for it and has been a huge time sink. The ways ships are designed is one of the best systems I have seen implemented in a game and one I wish other studios would adopt. Now I did not have many of the problems mentioned by most reviewers so I may have been lucky in that regard. The few crashes I did have were after marathon sessions of 12+ hours of playing. Over the years I tend to encounter very few bugs or other issues in games so I may just be very lucky.Some of the mechanics weren't well explained but a little trial and error would produce the answer. In my experience if no explanation or trial and error is needed to figure out how a game works then the game has been dumbed down and will offer very little. I've seen a lot of complaints about the developer not finishing the game and other issues but it ended up being exactly what I expected it to be. Personally, I got my money's worth of entertainment from this game and then some. I have even recommended it to a few friends who have also enjoyed it.

												Well, I could write a long review but, to me, the game is just not worth it.Don't get me wrong, it has potential and modders could possibly turn it into something really great, but sadly the dev decided to abandon the game. Promises made during the kickstarter campaign as well as during the alpha and beta phase will never be fulfilled cos it would just not be lucrative. Instead of working on StarDrive the dev decided to rather create a new game, which is basically StarDrive but is using the Unity engine instead. And, of course, if you bought the old game that now will never be finished you have to purchase the new one again, at full price.So, really guys, even though the game might be good, the dev really doesn't deserver your money.Another problem of StarDrive is the huge amount of censorship going on on both the official and Steam forums. If you want to avoid that pay this Steam group a visit: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVC/discussions

However, the developer is a bit of an idiot. He has abandoned the game to go on the a sequel. WITHOUT COMPLETEING THE FIRST GAME!!! (but it will have much better land combat, but no more real time space combat :( ) As well some of the promised features never ended up in game, and I would really, really love multiplayer! (which was promised) And finally, the ship design system is awsome and is completely modular so youu can change, edit and completely remake every ship. As a result, I belive you should either try this game for its realatively unique real time space (most other 4x games do this due to preformance problems) or wait for the sequel for a hopefully improved game.Edit:I'm now more optimistic(watched thexpgamer's video on it) about stardrive 2 cause it does have real time combat, but you can only place ships right in front of the enemy and can't get reinforcements in battle. So I might try and mod that in if it isn't that hasn't been done already(pasted directly from my comment, sorry for gramatical issues)

												A lack of a good tutorial makes this game very difficult to get into. Any 4X, complex strategy game should put a lot of effort into their tutorial otherwise they outcast newcomers to the genre. I'm not a veteran 4X gamer, but I've played my fair share. I eventually did sort of get the hang of everything, but the fact that I was forced to learn mostly manually made my choices very stilted and boring. Like I didn't want to declare war on anybody since I didn't really understand if I'd win or not. I also focused solely on economy because everything else seemed a bit more advanced.That said, the game was pretty decent, I just have zero interest in learning a new 4X game without proper learning tools. I'll go back and play SoaSE before I play this again.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												Stardrive is very reminiscent of the old school "Orion" PC series. This game lets you play the game however you wish; you can try and seize control of the universe through diplomacy, scientific progress, or sheer military might.  The game will often leave you with very open ended- decisions with you in full control of your ultimate destiny.  And at times when things don't turn out the way you wish, there are always more than one way to coming to a solution.  Stardrive will challenge your ability to think ahead, manage resources, and your strategic combat prowess to its full extent.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Fun enough, but absolutely no late game whatsoever. There's not much point researching ships bigger than frigates - all you need are some ships to keep the enemy's ridiculously weak fighter fleets at bay while you infantry rush them."Not finished", as others have said, in the sense that the whole game feels very shallow, but it's not buggy enough to really be considered a beta either - I'd call it a finished product, though it's not a great one. Not a bad game in some ways, but very little replay and not worth $30.Yeah, I know I have like 170 hours on this despite saying very little replay. To be frank, I don't usually complete my 4X games because I get frustrated with the late game grindy-ness, and thusly, I did get quite a bit of time on Stardrive, which does certain parts of the mid-game reasonably well. Besides that, I bet at least 100 of those hours was spent designing ships, which is probably the best designed aspect of the game.But unfortunately, that is the big issue with the game as well - designing ships, the most interesting part of the game, is not really actually all that important in terms of gameplay. You can certainly min-max the ♥♥♥♥ out of your transport ships, and design ultra-badass capital ships with hangers (which don't work, by the way) and plague bombs (because you can't blow up planets) and death rays, but in the end it doesn't really matter because you are really only going to build a bunch of frigates armed with super-missiles to crush the pathetic enemy fleet while you infantry rush him. Did I mention you can't blow up planets?It sounds like I'm ♥♥♥♥♥ing about a specific tactic that works too well, and that someone with my hours is probably just good at the game. What I'm really trying to do here is save you money - this is not the easiest way to win the game, it's how you play the game, period. If you don't do it, the ultra-slow AI will eventually do it to you after several hours of ingame time, or at least try to. I personally used that time to build up a giant empire and a fleet of death ships that squished his little army without me having to do much of anything. Then quit and restarted because I realized that, nope, that was it, and now I'd have to spend two hours invading defenseless planets after I stocked up on cans of SPAM.Not that you need an empire. You can easily ♥♥♥♥ everyone's day up with 10 planets if you are smart about what you build and research. Hint: Build and research everything, because the AI is slow as a turtle in concrete and will still be using popguns while you rock rocket launchers. There's also only a dozen or so things to build, and everyone has the same research trees, so you don't really need to prioritize well.All of this is somewhat redeemed by the multiplayer mode, though. Because humans are not slow as ♥♥♥♥, you actually need to play the game in a fashion that bears some semblance to strategy. Infantry spamming is still the only tactic, but you now do need a proper navy in order to get your troops to the ground. The community is vibrant and great, and you'll find that the people you play against generally are good folks who want to play the game rather than use these kinds of tactics however.Oh, right. :p

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game had potentiall. It really did.Unfortunately, the best I could say about this game is "unfinished". It's got some interesting races, sure, some humor as well, a decent amount of exploration, but at nearly every turn you run into something that just seems... unfinished. Ship classes? Not all implemented for all races yet, so some people get titans, some don't. Follow up an ancient mystery? Your reward is... fighting a giant ship. More than once, if you'd like. First contact? Never mind, that's been cut. Endings? Blow up everyone you're not allied to, that's the only way to win last I checked. The end-game optimization was also lacking, causing the game to choke horribly during battles.In short? If you want a great 4X game, buy something like Master of Orion 2 off GoG. It'll be cheaper AND provide more fun than this game, in its current state.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												After reading through the piles of negative reviews, I just had to throw my 2 cents into the debate.  Initially I kept getting crushed every game, leading me to concur with negative review posse. However, after giving StarDrive a chance,I feel like it will depend on the individuals 4x gaming expectation. Although there are some issues, StartDrive is a little more nuanced in some areas than others have indicated,for instance, you can join or form alliances, develope a spy network to gain tactical advantage by stealing tech or by sabotaging rival civs covertly. Designing ship loadouts is cool cause it lets you upgrade your fleets tactical capabilities as needed to expand your empire,strengthen alliances and crush the opposition. I enjoyed using covert methods to aquire, or to sabotage a rival civ .I found that SD offers an unpredictable, quirky style that might change whats expected in a 4x space title. In summary SD marries an asymetrical  universe with challenging 4x game play, Stardrive marches to its own drummer  with some in game quirks, but I its worth the price of admission. By the way, the Black Box Mod expands player options and reduces a lot of the the unwanted quirks. I say buy it!!!

Unless you have 120 GB of RAM, a 16 core processor, and 100 terabytes of storage I don't recommend this game... especially at 30 dollars. Knowing what I know now, I should not have paid more than 5 dollars for this game because the developer just gave up on it and is hoping to go through the exact same mess with stardrive 2 instead of updating THIS.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												If I could give a sideways thumb, I'd give one.  I liked the game because it reminded me of Masters of Orion, except not turn based. That said, I'm willing to bet that there are games in the genre that pay MoO homage much better than this one.  The most striking thing about this game is it doesn't feel quite complete.  I was shocked to see that they were coming out with a sequel to it, mainly because I had a hard time believing that this game was finished.  Hours of playing it and I still haven't managed to finish a game.  They've released several updates for it, but the game still doesn't feel whole, even in its current state.I'd really like to give this game a thumb up, but an overall feeling of incomplete game design, and rushed development ruin it for me.  A good game, but not a great one.  Definitely doesn't live up to the original that started the genre.

content:

												StarDrive, a really immersive and fun game you'll get hooked on almost immediately. Starting of as one of the sentient races, you need to colonize, harvest, supply and defend your very own existence from those who would crush it (in most cases, everyone!). Build and design your own layout of each ship, you can have multiple different designs, but remember that the more you put on it - the more costly it becomes.You can customize your race's special benefits at the game lobby screen, although it's Single-player only, it has a lot of interesting play methods.I sincerely recommend this to Sci-fi, Strategy, Slow-paced genre lovers. It won't let you down!

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I highly recommend this one. It is already well polished for an Early Access game and I daresay is better that some AAA titles that have been released in their final stages.The races are varied and interesting on it's own and it even allows you to customize them to suit your own needs while still remaining in a somewhat balanced state.The ship building is easy and fun, if I had one critique though, I wish there was a way to test my builds before seeing them utterly fail in battle because I didn't know how a module will react. That said, as it is now is plenty good enough to enjoy the game.Pros:- Playable and polished even in early stages, loads of fun to be had- Races are a joy to behold as they are varied and rather humorous in their depiction- Easy to learn, difficult to master makes this something even a newbie in the genre can pick up.Cons: *but this could change*- Currently, ship building doesn't have a way to test builds so guides might be necessary there- Increasing tax doesn't seem to have any negative impact at the moment or no value for measurement (ex: colonist morale)- Enemy ships don't display their insignia so it could take some practice to know who's fleet is whose in game.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												When I first purchased this game, I was very concerned when I read all the reviews. I should have known better than to purchase a game without reading the reviews. As stated by the reviews, the game was unplayable due to excessive bugs and lag when first downloaded. However, one thing that I have found very strange about this game is that the more you play it and the more you explore, the less likely bugs are to occur (kindof like the exact opposite of Minecraft). IDK if this happens on everyone's computer or if it is just a wierd quirk of mine, and I have no idea how this could happen in terms of programming, but for about the last hour of playtime (about at 10ish hrs.), I have never seen any lag or not registering clicks to the degree that I first experienced it in the game. I still have some pretty significant trouble with the game not registering my mouse clicks, but it has become at least playable, and the problem is now only a minor annoyance, unlike the total hairpulling frustration upon first download. Sometimes, due to lag, it still registers that I clicked on something that I moused over earlier, rather than what I actually have my mouse over at the time of the click. I wonder if a similar phenomenon caused the programmer(s) to think that the bugs were fixed when they were unable to reproduce reported bugs. If you have the patience for the bugs, the game itself isn't too bad. The ability to adjust your species for tactical, RP, or mixed  gameplay allows you to play a species according to your own interpretation of how they are or what they could be. I prefer a much more strategic and magical Vulfen to the brutish, early-game swarmers version that they are set to by default (retaining their militaristic tendancies, because IMO Vulfen aren't really Vulfen if they are too peaceful, but upon player preferance this could be changed too). It does have a fairly Star Trek/Babylon 5 type feel, which I very much appreciate. Diplomacy is critical, and there is a high degree of intrigue involved (though taking the few abilities and technologies for intrigue that exist will make it very simple, as max rank agents can pretty much do as they please at this point, only occasionally getting discovered or even foiled but not killed). Players should keep in mind, however, that there are few guides to this game, and the videos that are out there regarding this game often do not involve enough information to really give you the feel for things. With no tutorials missions, you will likely be completely lost in the beginning, even with deep research. For this reason, I would advise setting up your first species to give you a large margin for error. Additionally, I found race customization to be very confusing initially, but once you get it, it is very straightforward. I have come to enjoy the game in time, but I cannot bring myself to recommend this game for its current price. It is simply too high.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												I could go on for minutes apon minutes on how this game is dreary, drab and overpriced but I'm gonna keep it short. So lets begin.While the game isn't buggy or unpolished by any means, it's because of the majority of it's design is absolutley awful, not to say everything is ♥♥♥♥♥♥, just most of it. Like the music, a fundamental part of any strategy game whether it's Master Of Orion or Civilization, the music is there to make you feel like a commander of a thousand fleets or a cultured world leader, and in both of the games mentioned the game does a great job doing that. But in StarDrive it's... uhhh...♥♥♥♥♥♥ The music sucks♥♥♥♥♥ It's a bunch of dreary melodies with a few space feeling instrumentals but all of them lack any sense of excitment. And that's the main problem, this game lacks excitment... or fun... or a reason to exist.I like ProJared's description of the game in his One Minute Review of the game. Hopefully ProJared doesn't mind that I'm gonna quote him."It's like they took Master Of Orion 2 and made it realtime and then SUCKED all the fun right out of it."That sentence alone can describe the whole game. Really, I could've stopped over a paragraph ago because that perfectly describes this game. And did I mention how this game is as slow as a snail in molases in a slow motion field? Even on the highest speed setting before you start, everything goes so SLOOOOWWWWW that you get bored after five minutes, even with the slightly cool shipyard (I say slightly cool because the best ship designs are the presets so you'll never need to use the shipyard) and the very amusing races. The game is so drab that it counteracts the good, and the game IS UNFORGIVABLY UNFAIR, meaning even on the easiest difficulty the A.I will CRUSH YOU UNDER THEIR BOOTS OF UNBEARABLE CRUELTY AND DELERIUM.Long story short, don't buy this overpriced crap, buy Endless Space, or hell, If your feeling nostalgic go on GOG.com and pick up Master Of Orion 1+2 for £5 or less. Don't bear the same pain that I did.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Star DriveThis is a pretty decent game. It runs in real time as do the space battles. Ships can be commanded in space battles for full control of targeting.Ship design is really neat. Hulls come as is and may be filled with all sorts of space combat goodies. THis is a cool part of the game.Tech research is pretty neat. There are not a lot of techs but what is there is good.The alien races are all distinct and filled with personality. There is also cusomization for your race if you want it. The developer moved on to their next game, Star Drive 2, and they are very active in that title. This game has all that is needed to wage war and conquer the stars. It may be missing some fleshed out things but the game is definitely playable and fun.Oh, and ground battles are turn based with control over each troop. Pretty cool.

												I've had a couple stability and speed issues with StarDrive despite plenty of memory and being well over the GPU and CPU requirements for the game. Starting the game for example takes several minutes before I even get the intro videos everybody always skips.Nonetheless, once in the game I generall have a great time. The AI can be overly aggressive, but it draws a good balance between races which attack weaker prey, races who declare war because they see you as a threat, and races who could be peaceful allies (on conquerable foes, depending on your gaming style.)I'd like to see some small additions, like the ability to save custom race settings and either have them in a droplist or loadable from a file like they already have for custom ship designs.I really enjoy StarDrive. If you like space conquest games, this one's a good buy.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Basically its a space empires 4/5 with better graphics, also bears some resemblance to master of orion -> colony managment is quite similiar if nor borderline the same -> so if you liked those games you should like this one too -> but that said the game has some cons as well -> tech tree seems kinda limited -> but the game is highly modable via simple notepad if you care to do so (with some understanding how the coding works) so you can adjust it to your liking if you care to do so (imho a big plus), Ship behaviour can be annoying at times, also i find some control options to be lacking -> for eg you can select one cargo ship and set its destination and what should it carry but you can do the same en masse with several at once -> which can be annoying when you build 10 of them and have to adjust each one in the same manner aka takes time and it can get tedious, fighter bays cane be exaple of this -> i had 10 carriers -> and form each one i had to launch fighters manyally aka select it then click the icon in its tab -> you cant select them all and press one button for that -> it can be bothersome in battle conditions. Also colony managment can get tedious if you have a lot of them . So yes the game does have some flaws but imho its a good game also nice graphics ans sounds make it immersive -> im a great fan of this genre so i love it ;) but some ppl might not like it -> due to tediousness or relatively slow dynamic at first. Also the game dev moved on so expect no new stuff from him -> either mod it yourself or get some mods from the community.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												This game is an unpolished GEM. The gameplay is great, controlling the ship layout for your personal play style, and ability to modify your own race are just examples of how much control a player can have.Yes, like all games, it does have its bugs here and there. They have seemed minor from my perspective, and far from game breaking. Crashing is infrequent once you realize what settings your computer can handle as it is a hardware hungry game. Don't play with anything less than the reccomended equipment.There are some things that I would have loved to see done differently but I'm not the one who created the game, I'm a player that, like all other players, wants things in my favor. Things aren't breazy easy, you have to play and fight the challenges.I reccomend grabbing this game and accepting that it is a gem in the rough. I am looking forward to StarDrive 2!

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Played since Alpha so the 6h aren't exactly accurate.Let's put it easy, the game isn't bad. It isn't outstanding either. It has some nice ideas especially the shipdesigner is great, probably the best around and watching the spacebattles is real fun (I say "watching", because the pilots do not really need your help once the dogfight starts). On the other hand the empiremanagement is very unchallengeing, almost nothing to do and to put it blunt: Best you leave it to the AI so you can concentrate on the big picture.Now, what is the problem with this game? Why wouldn't I recommend it?Well my downgrade has nothing to do with the quality of the game itself, but with the simple problem that the developer didn't implement all the features promised, but instead realises them in a different version of the game named "Stardrive 2". I wouldn't complain if he simply made part 1 and then turned to work on a better part 2, like many other developers do. But he's implementing features in part 2 that were explicitly promised for part 1.So, downgrade for bad management. But if you enjoy ship desinging and watching space combat, you might give it a shot if you can get it for a 75% discount.

												An excellent game! Very unique, although complex, an immensly fun time. After I got over the hefty learning curve (SINCE THEY DONT HAVE ANY USEFUL TUTORIALS!!!) I immediately fell in love with the game. Being able to manufacture my own ships for my own means is way more fun that I had imagined. Although there are some aspects to the game that is lacking, in particular the weak diplomacy system, the combat is thrilling, and taking over the galaxy is always a good time.Cons, as I stated the tutorials are just non-existant. The AI can be predictable if not boring. And frankly I'm not sure why they even implemented their diplomacy system. Maybe I just don't understand it's mechanics yet, but after playing for nine hours I feel like I should've mastered it, assuming it was functional. The lack of options within the menu can be annoying, there are no difficulty settings. The AI just automagically decide how hard they want to kill you. There are still a lot of annoying bugs. Specifically speaking, large capital ships tend to get "stuck" although their icons continue to move. Ships randomly decide they dont want to attack, but that's more infrequent.Overall, I give this game an 8/10. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is into large scale space battles.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												So Stardrive has a lot going for it. The ability to design each ship piece by piece and then set their AI. Want a large slow ship with all weapons pointing forward to hammer other large ships? What about making it lighter and pointing all the weapons to the sides and have it strafe through destroying smaller ships? Swap out those weapons for fighter bays and launch swarms of fighter ships. Don't like cannons? Switch out to missiles or lasers. Load it with emp weapons to disable other ships or tractor beams to bring fast ships to a halt and rip them apart with cannon fire.Each race oozes with their own personality. From samuri space bears to mechanical hive mind of the Opertis.Build a grand empire of planets. Forge treaties and even a federation with long time allies. The diplomacy system is not ground breaking but quite adequate.The only down side, and it's a big one, is the slow down you experience late game. No matter how beastly your PC is the game is going to crawl latter on when each race has hundreds of ships and are duking it out with each other.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Another entry in the booming "4x Space Strategy" genre being populated by both established development teams and indies, StarDrive comes to the table burdened by a negative reputation but with more than a few strengths in its corner. No one will deny that StarDrive was released way too early to the public. It was buggy, incomplete, and, as a result, it entirely deserved the low scores it received.Since release, however, the developers have worked hard to plug the holes and fill the gaps. The game is now, especially on sale, one that I would recommend to anyone who enjoys this genre. The strongest differentiator that sets StarDrive apart from competitors is the ship design. While some games allow you to choose your ship's weapons or shields, in StarDrive you build a ship from an empty hull to a bristling space cruiser. You select exactly where you want bulkheads, power plants, command centers, weapon banks, and sheild generators to be placed. As the research tree fills in, you'll open up even more opportunities to build new, larger hulls or moditfy your existing blueprints. Another area I enjoyed in StarDrive was the factions. Each faction is extremely unique in design and carries with it a lot of flavor. Whether your negotiating with the honorable but militant pandas or the robotic faction that's enslaved a race of owls - you'll find interactions to be a lot more interesting than the sterile diplomacy of many other games in this genre. In the end, StarDrive is exactly what it sets out to be: a 4x Space Strategy game with a robust ship builder and real time combat. If that sounds like it's up your alley, then I think you won't be dissapointed.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												StarDrive will provide a fix you've been craving all these years since MoO2.  Is it the complete experience you've long for? Unfortunately, no, probably not.  However, a good selection of features, and the module layout based ship creator, allow for some classic MoO style fun and enjoyment.The original launch of the game in early access had some issues from what I've read, but StarDrive was one of those games on my "To Play" list for almost a year before finally coming around to it after the latest patch (1.15 of this writing).  The core gameplay is there, but a tech tree that's lacking much depth is probably the most glaring flaw I've experienced in my playthroughs.This lack, thankfully, can be remedied with a mod which adds much more MoO-like tech tree into the game.  The current non-mod tech layout allows for a very balanced approach that was likely intended for multiplayer(which as of yet hasn't surfaced), with early ship designs still being marginally useful against even high tech ships late in the game.  For fans of MoO2 and it's tech singularity that often happened late game (Psilons, anyone?), this is a mixed blessing.As mentioned earlier, the ship creator is the main feature of the game, and the one I've had the most enjoyment from.  Going in blind, you'll come up with design iteration after iteration, and love each one as much as the one before.  Every module has a certain length and width that you try and shoehorn into the various ship hulls, with each race having a specific design.  There's generally an overall "feel" for each race's ships (such as long, relatively narrow hulls that allow for greater head on armor layouts for Terrans, or a greater number of possible weaponry on Kulrathi), and even the actual shape of the ship's hull can have very drastic effect when combat comes to your fleets.There is a slew of ease of use features in the game which makes play more friendly on the UI front.  Unfortunately, a lack of any decent game provided documentation makes some of these a complete secret until they're stumbled upon and discovered.  Definately do some searching for UI tips and tricks for this one.The tougher AI levels allows for some challenge, but expect the game to be a fairly easy breeze until you design some better ships for the AI to utilize.  The game has some of the spark of MoO, but it's not a drop-in replacement for it.Overall, I'm in love with StarDrive for what it is, not what it was promised or wished to be.  At it's core, it's engaging and enjoyable.  Hopefully the next offering from Zero Sum will be full spiritual successor that we long for, but this one is better than most MoO clones that pop up now and again.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Oh, StarDrive. Where do I start with you? You're the most promising space-themed Strategy game I've played, and that's both good and bad. You can be challenging at times, and despite having the re-playability of a 10 year-old's view of Peace and War, terrible, the fact that you are updated once every now and then has me sitting in bed, staring at the ceiling, wondering, "What will be next?" This game has far to go before reaching the elite status, but the steps it must take are simple things to add. This game has one play mode, Sandbox, in which starting out, you have one planet and a few spaceships, and you must find a way to colonize beneficial planets on the road to galactic empire. Other alien species will be right next door, and your actions can (possibly) decide whether or not war will ensue. There is a full tech tree and a very simple, yet important management system that you, as leader, must lead. Sweet and ultimate victory will not be achieved until every species you meet is either your friend (boring) or completely eradicated to the point of extinction (yay). If you decide to be an Adolf Hitler, you can with the ability to bombard any planet's (and I mean ANY) surface with nuclear weapons and murder every last thing that resided there. Did I mention there is also a full ship constructor as well? You can create your own vision of whatever the Super Star Destroyer was in Episode VI of Star Wars during the two minutes it was on screen, and giant, flying pieces of metal with a million death rays are always fun. But this game is SOOOO repetitive! Every game you start up will have the same sequence of events happen, and no matter what you do, they always seem to take place. There's no multiplayer(Note to creator of StarDrive: Make this happen!), and even with mod support, what is in the game to be modded will take a LOT of creativity to make something out of. This game is fun, don't get me wrong, but in order for a consumer to get his/her money's worth PLEASE wait for a sale(like me). ZeroSum, you have a rough diamond here, and polishing has been done, but it is far from the Hope Diamond. 7.25/10.

Posted: February 6, 2014
												I been wasting a ton of time(fun time) in fact about 354 steam record hours(not steam play throw in many more hours). I simply love this space space strategy game. its almost like old school turn base but its real time. so use pause alot when clicking on some things. reminds me of starcontrol and starcontrol two. But you can built a empire!Ship design is for me the heart of the game, ship hulls are different for different civilizations. The fun part is how you use different components into the ship design to beat the other civilizations. since they have access to the same tech research as you. seeing your superior designs destroy them!! LIke a fleet of meat into your meatgrinder!For example my favorite is the Kulrathi aka bearmen their ships might not be the fastest(not too many engine slots, you can put in different type of engines into that slot). but their fighter are the largest in the game. I love putting in fighter bays(they spawn fighters(free fighters)) into all my Titan ships(they are the largest hull type every civilization gets, each civilization has different sizes and shapes of that hull). I love putting in remnant shields onto the fighters and tons of weapons and no wrapdrive only thrust. They can be respawn from the carrier. Park the carrier slightly farther away from the fighting. wave after wave of fighters just destroy anything in their path.With many patches later they fix the Remnant quest. Also remnant tech is always the most powerful in game. There are a few mods out there but the ones that still out there is fun.

												Loved playing a game called Starflight when I was a kid.  Its the great grand dad of this game.  Stardrive goes way beyond Starflight in every way.  Stardrive is a lot of fun if you like strategy games. number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												This game is very unpolished, but still fun.(A lot of things are fixed by two mods I use, the 'Black Box' mod and the Tech Level Mod)1. Ship designing:This is excellent; module positioning really matters in combat. If you fill the interior with lots of reactors, they'll blow up when destroyed and will probably destroy your ship from the inside out.Shields are not 'all around' your ship but instead only protect areas they're near to, so don't forget to place lots of armour to soak up the hits that get through.There really aren't enough ship hulls and modules; each empire only gets 1 hull for each hull type (i.e. frigate, cruiser, battleship, titan etc.). Reactors never get an upgrade. Sub-light maneuvering speeds are much too low.2. AI:The AI for the other players is poor - they don't expand very much and they have a tendency to get angry about every single system you colonise. They are very, very bad at fighting and will only cause you trouble if you ignore your military for the entire game (which they'll also taunt you for doing). Their art however is really nice and each empire has its own set of ship types.There's a nice automation dialogue that lets you automate the building and usage of scouts, freighters, and subspace projectors.3. Research:Research feels a little slow for me. The tech tree is pretty sparse and could use some more mid/end-tier stuff.There are two (maybe three?) 'discovered' secret techs which appear according to what you do in the game. This is something the developer never got around to adding more of, which is a real shame.4. Early Access 'dev didn't implement X':I hear this a lot, and it seems to make up most of the reviews here. This game does feel like the dev gave up when it was 80% finished. I didn't buy this game in Early Access (Humble Bundle had it for $4) so if you're not sure, buy this on sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												  Good game, IF, you like 4x strategy games. I am a fan of this game but there could be a lot more to it seeing how old it is. However for the time, effort, and abilities of Zerosum Games it is a good game. There are ups and downs to the game. (A lot of downs)  There are a few bad things about the game though. First there are some lag issues and stability problems. The game lags a bit when a lot of action is going on in a large galaxy. Second is mods. The whole game relies on mods at this stage to keep players interested and the game has a open mod folder to simply load one into. The website even comes with a tutorial on how to mod the game. Third is you have to be very meticulous to see what is going on when and where.   The game focuses more on combat than economy or events. The game has events but none have any significance or really game changing results whether that'd be good or bad. Events have changed over the year this game has officialy been out, that means a few events were removed, others added or tweeked. Economy is good but needs more to it as well. The game has two resources, food and production. Food is used to feed your race and production is used from building structures to ships. Other than that it doesnt get any more complicated. The only tricky thing about economies is taxing and distributing resources.   Combat offers a lot to the game seeing how that is the soul focus of gameplay. Ships can be custom designed with a traditional grid pattern and using moduels to fill them in. The possibilities are practicaly endless when it comes to combat.   Dev did abandon the game unfortunatly. After the full game came out updates have become rare. The game has absolutely no purpose but sort of sandbox game letting you do as you please. The only downside to that is there is no story to the game, no story or big explanation about the mysterious "Remnant" race. All we get as far as story to any AI alien race is a short three sentence paragraph FROM the AI. And all we get for story behind the "remnant" is a short mini event quest that, when summed up, gives literaly a short two paragraph explanation on them.   The game feels very open and at times too open. There needs to be more content before this becomes a real game because at this stage it does seem like a very high quality app than a full game.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Time for some positive reinforcement. Star Drive a unique 4x game in that it does everything in real time. Now, Sins of a Solar Empire did the same, but get this: no phase lines here!  Go any where you want! This can lead to some preformance issues, as when you have transport ferrying things between planets and a  fleet fighting a bunch of ships at the same time things can slow down a bit. Also keep in mind this is not Space Empires, the rules here are differnt, you will have a bit of a learning curve here to learn the rules of this game. The Galaxy is also kinda bland. There are not many features in it besides Planets and Stars, you will not be encountering asteroids, a  Black Hole, or nebulas.However, the game it's self is fun and worth a look if you are a fan of 4X space games. The ability to design your own ships is nice, and the game has some cool visual effects. The differt empires you come across are full of character and varied.  The same planet rush situation is present in this game, grab what you can when you first start, but make sure you chose rigth and supply the planet with food until it can produce on its own!Cons-  not all features in when it first came out-  tech tree not that extensive... but there are mods you can easly add in.-  Map has planets and Stars, not a whole lot more then that. Pros-  Unique real time 4X game for those of you tired of hitting the end turn button. ships go boom.-  Exploring the galaxy and encountering the races is alwasys fun in this game.-  Mod support. -  Designing your own ships is fun.All in all, this is a decent game..... When its on sale. I don't know about the $30 price tag. But if you are willing to support an indie developer with some cool ideas then give it a shot.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												A nifty little game. Sure its a little buggy, is missing many features and lags pretty bad during the endgame, but if we only focus on the negatives in life we end up like Hitler, or Cersei Lannister.The good features far outweigh the bad, and I have had a brief addiction with this game. THE most fun thing to is obviously the ship design. In my experience, you can take the basic frieght ship from the start of the game, outfit it with nuclear reactors, and then crash them into the enemy. You can create ships, that spew out dozens of tiny fighter drones. You can create ships bristling with poisonous spores, and then bombard your helpless enemies ground forces. You can assume direct control over titan ships, driving them like Jesse Pinkman in the Need for Speed movie. You can launch an armada of mobile space marines that can board and control enemy ships. I could keep going for a long time. Every piece of this game isn't just a statistic that somehow affects the game. If you research something, you will be able to see it, and use it. If you give some technology to another race, they will remember your kindness (even if they remember it as they are using that same technology to annihalate you).Ive gone on for longer than i intended which just goes to show how much I like this game. In summary, StarDrive is an acquired taste. Like Dark Souls, coffee or Selena Gomez.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I found the game to be quite enjoyable if a bit rough on the edges.  The one downfal is how essential your starting placement is.  Dont have enough early colony's available with some expansion planets in them you will have a severe disadvantage moving forward.  That said, the long game is just that, long.  Expect to dedicate time to keeping your fleet up to date and include it in your stratagey.  Multiple smaller fleets are the way to push ahead so one can be out expanding your empire while another is defending it while another is being refit.  All in all I do say a 60% is a deserving score, and not bad for a first game out.  While there are better 4X games out there, I dont feel I got shorted on what I payed.  Put more than enough hours in to justify the money.  Its a shame that he has to scrap the whole game to change direction, but making the move to turn based in the sequil will play better with the modular ship design.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												StarDrive gameplay takes place in real time. During skirmishes with opponents a player can take direct control of any unit subordinate to it, which greatly enlivens the battle. The creators also took care of the possibility of customization of weapons and equipment of each spacecraft. With the appropriate modules, each of the spacecraft can be adapted to specific tasks (for example,. Putting mines, shielding other units, transportation of raw materials). The game is distinguished by aesthetic visuals. Attention is drawn primarily attractive views of space and animated feature films cutscenes. As a minus I add - no optimization of the game. A few hours of play and the game sometimes freezes.
