content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Space combat is exceptional due to the ship design and research systems. A must have for shipbuilders. And, it's real time strategy, no turns here. Ground combat is terrible, I hope they leave it out of StarDrive 2 alltogether. It just gets in the way of space combat!Diplomacy is straightforward; AI will either friend you, or declare war right off the bat. Makes things interesting. Although, the only way to win is to kill everyone. Even your friend, Mr. Treesong.Racial graphics look very nice, sort of a high quality Flash display with artistic flair.Space weapon effects are pretty good, especially the laser turrets. I always make sure to spam those. XDI'm not sure why it's still priced at $30. Buy it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Having no idea of what the game was "supposed" to be, I simply bought the game expecting a fancier "MOO2" so to speak.    And given the negative reviews I kept reading about it, I lowered my expectations greatly and bought the game on massive sale.Once I actually played the game, I actually wound up enjoying it quite a bit.   I can't recall how many hours I've spent and how many "races" I've created in trying the game.  I'll try to rate the game on a 5-star system on each of the areas that I can think of:1.) Graphics - 4/5- I truly enjoyed the graphics.  I really did.  Being able to zoom in to my ships, the combat animations, the effects of each weapon being unique in their own right.  I especially like the unique ship designs for each race which attempted to match their species.  A little cliched, but then again, what game isn't nowadays?2.) UI - 3/5- Simple enough and inuitive.  A few grips would be on some screens where it seems like the UI was designed with a different resolution in mind.  I have an old monitor only capable of 1280 x 1024 and it stuggles on the setup screen due to odd text wrapping.  Other than that however, I felt the UI easy enough to navigate.3.) Gameplay - 3.5/5- I found myself in several sleepless nights playing that "one more turn" (or in this case, one more minute given it's real time).  The racial creation allows for varied types of empires to play around with and with each game randomizing the different empires behavior, it's always been a treat for me.  However, there is one glaring bug around the "plot" where if the AI winds up wiping out the triggers, you're SoL if that was your main goal for that particular round of gameplay.  I've actually had to go in to the XML save files to try to re-trigger the events which is never a good sign.  Still, that plot isn't the end-all-be-all of the game and isn't a deal-breaker for me.  - Another nice twist is the actual race creator.  Unlike a true "creator", you simply overwrite a species for the current game.  However, any designs you create while playing that "race" become available to the AI in succeeding games so you eventually wind up fighting your own designs which was a real treat when I saw it happen.- Related to gamelay, there are a few things which could have been improved on in my opinion.   Tech Tree, for one, is smaller compared to other 4X games.  It only feels large due to the amount of research points needed to unlock higher tiers.  The AI also sometimes behaves oddly despite their racial setting at game time (i.e. an Honorable AI will sometimes keep stealing from you despite being in an non-agression pact).4.)  Replayability - 3/5- I admit I keep replaying the game.  For me, it's been enjoyable.  However, I do see 2 problems which can hinder it in other cases:   a) Memory optimization: unlike other RTS games (which this game has flavors of), there is no unit cap other than your bank account (i.e. turn-by-turn income).  This is both a blessing and curse.  This means that you can build up quite the fleet and swarm your way through the galaxy.  Unfortunately this also means unless you've got godly amounts of RAM (and I'm talking 16+ GB of RAM), your game can quickly grind to a halt and crash as the AI will spam ships like no tomorrow.   Even the "final plot story" can break your game should you unlock it given that it also spams ships like no tomorrow (without the limitation of a factory's output to slow it down).  Related to this, beware of designing "cheap" gunboats.  As the race creator "overwrites" a species, any design you create becomes available to that AI race and it tends to favor spamming those cheap gunboats.   b) No multiplayer.  I never expected this feature as I never was an early backer.  I can see how this would put off others as the challenge of beating down your frenemies always extends the life of a game.  The lack of this feature can put off many people from getting the game.   c) Lack of a real "custom" race.  MOO2 had the same issues but it would have been nice to have a custom race that didn't overwrite existing ones.5.) Overall - 3/5- I liked MOO3.  Yes, I said it.  I actually came to like game.  StarDrive feels like what MOO3 tried to be.  4X strategy with RTS gameplay.  StarDrive for me is an enjoyable single-player 4X game which allows for some small to medium scale games.  Large games are completely out of the question due to the memory problem which would have raised the game to 4/5 or me.  If you ignore what was originally promised and take the game for what it is now, it's actually worth a try.I would purchase it when it's at least 50% off given the isssues and replayability challenges it may give others.   For the current price of $32.99 CDN, I would instead spend it on Space Empires V or Pandora as they have a bit more replayability for most in my opinion.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I feel compelled to review this game as it has been recieving alot of hate due to claims that the developer had promised more content and had since reneged, which if true is of course morally reprehensible. However from an objective standpoint i can't possibly call it a bad game, quite the opposite. As a person who doesn't play alot of strategy games but enjoys a select few, i not only think this game is excellent but my favorite space strategy game that I have ever played. The controls and interface are both simple and easy to use/learn, the graphics are excellent (for an indie game) and the diplomacy is amazing where you start in a neutral position and actually have options besides war against some races. The ship building is deep and complex and requires alot of thought and balancing. The whole game is exceptionally balanced (weapons, armor, species creation) and finally the races are varied and each have their own distinct personallity. If I have any gripes it would be that the "tutorial" doesn't really tell you much and there is alot you will need to figure out yourself (or google). I for one am looking foward to the sequel and also hope the developer has learned his lesson from all the negative reviews.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												TL/DR: An average 4X game with a few charming features counterpointed by an overall feeling of an incomplete game.I picked up StarDrive through a bundle pack and I admit that after about half an hour I metaphorically put the game back on the shelf for a couple of months before trying it again in earnest.The learning curve is steep and the limited in-game help is definitely not intuitive, I wound up having the wiki and forums open on my second monitor and tabbing out to it every few minutes until I finally got the basics (about 8 hours and several games in).The Ai is... childlike, it's incredibly easy to trick and throws a diplomatic tantrum at the drop of a hat. It felt like I was playing against a group of stroppy children (not helped by the Pollop race's dialog) and after a while it ceased being humerous and just became annoying.The space combat is... interesting, the developers have obviously tried to use newtonian physics in the combat and it actually does feel quite good.... until your cruiser power-slides round a planet or your ships refuse to orbit a planet.The ground combat is..... horrific, and not in an amusing way either. it's clunky and feels like a bad browser game interface.The ship customisation though is a serious strong point for this game and for me it almost outweighs all the annoyances and the learning curve. I probably spent almost as much time in the shipyard over the past couple of days as I have actually playing the game.The tech tree and progression is okay, though it's pretty obvious that half the tech concepts are inspired by, if not simply ripped from, the Star Trek universe. Polaron, phasor (yes, they just swapped an e for an o), disruptor etc.In summary, if you get it with a bundle or you REALLY want to try it and it's a slow weekend then go for it. For all it's issues, I found the experience enjoyable overall... even if I probably won't be playing the game any more.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												I love games like this. I wanted to like this game. I don't. There's probably a good game in there somewhere. The biggest problem is I couldn't get past the interface to get to the game that I wanted to like so much. The 3d graphics look very nice and are very well done, but at the expense of gameplay. It's far too easy to click on the wrong thing, and when you finally get it you're not sure what to do with it. This may have been easily remedied with some-holding on the developer's part, but the "tutorial" is almost nonexistent, just a bunch of static pages hanging off of the main menu that do little to describe what's going on.My biggest disappointment isn't with what this game is. It has obviously had alot of effort and care poured into it. My biggest disappointment is what it could have been with just a little more.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Edit: Having played the game for more than a couple of hours, I see the game falling apart in my hands. Glitches, crashes, saves corrupting, it all sucks. The basic gameplay is fun, but the game is unfinished, as-in prelaunch. It's a beta, not a finished product. The developers have completely moved onto a sequel instead of finished the game they already produced, and the reviews I'm hearing for that game sound exactly like this review. User content patches do what they can, but they can't finish the game for the producers.The overall gameplay is fun, if you can get past the awkward GUI.Ship building is complicated and fun. Building and conquering is well balanced. I just can't get past the GUI.Frankly, the GUI in this game is terrible, it's my number one complaint of this whole game. This is strange coming from the developers of Endless Space which has a perfect, smooth, awesome GUI. What's wrong with the GUI you ask? Several things.-Clicking on a button doesn't "always" click it. It just doesn't respond... it just.... doesn't....-Opening and closing the windows is awkward. The close button changes locations on every screen and disappears completely on others. -They tried to integrate some UI stuff from Endless Space, such as right clicking a window to make it close. However, it's not availble on every screen, so it just takes some testing and memorizing to find out which screen closes with right click which screen doesn't.-Information on several screens is just a mess, while on others it's just a massive block of text. Nothing seems to be organized very well or effeciently.-Ship selection is the biggest complaint I have of the GUI.      -You can make control groups just fine, but shift + # doesn't add the current selection to the #'d control group. Having the control group you want to add to selected and shift+click-drag doesn't help either because that selects non-military ships as well.     -You can't unselect a ship from the selection panel in the bottom left corner.     -Ships move at different speeds, but there's no way to make a fleet/control group to move at the speed of the slowest ship.Overall, it just feels strange to navigate the UI. Some may call this nit-picking, but I don't. A game like this needs a smooth and fluid UI to be able to manage everything easily and quickly, while getting all the information you need on the fly. This game does not deliver on that.Another con of this game is the sound design. When ships are fighting, most of the time, you don't hear anything at all. Sometimes you hear the ship firing, and you get a 1/100 chance for the sound of the weapons firing to BLOW OUT your speakers. Turning the volume down doesn't help because then you can't hear any of the other sounds in the game. So, inevitablly, you just end up turning off the sound completely to avoid the jump scare every few minutes.After muddling through this game's crummy GUI, getting my ears checked by my doctor, and reloading the game through the crashes and the MASSIVE glitches, I'd give this game a D. Would not recommend this headache.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												It has good promise. It has good looks.It unfortunately lacks polish.The game is unfinished in many regards, but to me more than anything else is the balancing system within it. It just doesn't feel rounded out well enough to truly be considered finished. There are some bugs, glitches, and at times a good deal of rough edges to it. The gameplay is clunky, its approach leaves it too easy to overlook the time spent and the overal mechanics are hit and miss. That issue of the feel hits me in two regards, and the major one is how the empire grows and develops feels forced, and does it in a way that makes growth sluggish untill you hit a stage of performance where you just jump leaps and bounds. the staggering hiccup there just jarrs the whole gameplay on edge. It shows in combat if you don't hit the growth right before the AI does and you try combat.Specifically the combat. systems designed to fulfil certain roles just don't. Many instances of the combat I am frustrated with how the AI will always outperform the player, and even on basic combat levels it shows to a starkingly annoying degree. The fleet system and ship controls on it sound good, but lacking that final polish to really make it a good system leaves much to be desired in combat - especially if you need to travel with ships capable of different speeds.I like the lpooks, some of the mechanics are done well I think - but lacking that balance and refinement to really turn this into a good game.If you want to see, wait for a good sale maybe, but I would argue just stay away.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												I reccomend it only in that you will have a fun game if you can keep the enemy from getting remenant technology and forcing a wonder victory on you. This game has a modding scene and they can help you out with that problem. A real plus for me is that you can copy the game and stick it on a thumbdrive and it works without steam. So if anything you can buy this one for the ability to build an offline library for your computer games. Like say if you travel a lot or cannot afford a constant internet connection. I don't think they patched this yet. Though if you like strategy games and are looking for an offline game, go buy Planetary Annihilation from the Uber Entertainment store. Not from Steam, if you want an offline copy for yourself to enjoy with the ability to host a LAN party. Star Drive does not have multiplayer local or otherwise. I'm on the fence about reccomending this, buy at your own risk. You can still have a load of fun with it though, perhaps wait for a sale or get Star Drive 2 if you don't care about DRM. Steam is DRM but it's only as restrictive as the developers want it to be, I do not know the DRM status of Star Drive 2.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												This game is a lesson in bad management and bad design practice.You simply do not promise features in a game if you cannot deliver them.  You can publish a list of features that you desire to add if possible, but you only promise the core elements.  And then once in production, you do not just abandon the project to start a new game, especially a sequel.  It is an unwritten contract between the dev and the buyer that you will deliver a working game with as few bug as possible.As this game exists, the dev simply wasted to many development hours on a single feature.  The ship designing options in this game are hands down one of the best that I have seen.  You have so much control within the constraints put in place.  However, the whole purpose of a ship design is to utilize it in its function, typically combat.  And while combat is decent and some what fun, you need an economy to support it, and Stardrive simply does not have a well working economic model.  In fact, the game ends up punishing you for the 1st 30 min to hour of play.  1st by making you feel like you need to grind a bunch of base technologies just to be capable of performing the basic functions of a 4x game.  You will need new planets to expand you economic abilities, but you will feel you need 4 technologies before you can successfully colonize a planet: a food tech, a production tech, an income tech, and the ability to expand on to prohibited terrain.  However, if you focus on these techs to quickly start expanding, the AI comes and smacks you around because your military is weak.  So lets say you focus on military techs (like guided missiles and armor; yah, no armor before this tech), your units are capable of carrying a basic fight, but the AI has now colonized any half-decent planet on the map.  But then you say to yourself, I've got a big military I will just invade a weaker AI.  Welp, hope your like rebels suddenly poping up on your worlds with no prior indication of unrest because your income rate cannot support even a half decent fleet unless you colonize new worlds.  But wait you say, I'll just build a smaller but higher tech fleet; nope.  Not enough fire power to successfully invade a AI held world because unsuprisingly the AI has a fleet just as big if just a bit smaller but like 3x the troops you were able to build.  And all of this early game will determine whether you will win or loose late game.However, this is not to say you cannot do well.  If you get lucky, the random map has placed habitable planets as neighboring systems, given you one of the less aggressive races as a neighbor, and not block those systems with hostile drones.  If you can survive this early game, the game can be a good bit of fun.  At least up until some late game bug or unfixed feature ends your fun.A game should not punish players for trying to perform the tasks the game demands or make them slog through a list of Techs that can make or brake their game just to successfully perform those tasks.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												I reccomend it only in that you will have a fun game if you can keep the enemy from getting remenant technology and forcing a wonder victory on you. This game has a modding scene and they can help you out with that problem. A real plus for me is that you can copy the game and stick it on a thumbdrive and it works without steam. So if anything you can buy this one for the ability to build an offline library for your computer games. Like say if you travel a lot or cannot afford a constant internet connection. I don't think they patched this yet. Though if you like strategy games and are looking for an offline game, go buy Planetary Annihilation from the Uber Entertainment store. Not from Steam, if you want an offline copy for yourself to enjoy with the ability to host a LAN party. Star Drive does not have multiplayer local or otherwise. I'm on the fence about reccomending this, buy at your own risk. You can still have a load of fun with it though, perhaps wait for a sale or get Star Drive 2 if you don't care about DRM. Steam is DRM but it's only as restrictive as the developers want it to be, I do not know the DRM status of Star Drive 2.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												From the brief time of early access to the first release of the game, there was no new update, since then, it has only been minor tweaks, few and far between. Before early access, there was promises of a fully fleshed out experience. During early access, those promises remained. A few moments after first release, the dev stated that he will no longer be working on this game, so he may have time on his newer game which will be almost exactly like this game, only in a different engine, and hopefully better. He has also said that he plans to give all those who have bought StarDrive a discount on his next game, whenever it's released on Steam. Who knows how much of a discount that will be. Take a risk, buy this game discounted heavily in hopes that it will make the next game cheaper than the full priced original. Play this as the alpha that will never be finished. Don't buy this as a finished game, or even one that you expect future development on.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												An absolute blast.Stardrive is one of the many 'space-sims' currently on the market.Expand. Research. Build. Conquer.The same thing in all of them pretty much and i had alot of problems deciding wich one i'd settle with.Sure. This one might not have the graphics but it has alot of gameplay value. I love it and it didnt take long before it became my favorite space-sim.Mostly because of the sole fact that you can build your own spaceships. Decide what components goes where and strategically place the guns, engines, armor, fuel, batteries, sheilds, ammo, mass fabricators, wires, command modules... And the list goes on and on.Research and always be one step ahead of the enemy in various fields. Wether you try to improve the economy and food production or expansion. Wether that'd be by force or settleing on uncharted worlds.But building those capital-ships with onboard nukes. Boarding parties. Massive guns and fighter hangars? Wow. I love spending hours upon hours deciding the tiniest detail on my newest weapon of war.8/10 for this type of game. Only thing missing is current-gen graphics.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												This game is a complete and infinite sandbox amalgamation of two of history's most prominant pioneers of deep space pioneer exploration game franchises; Master of Orion 1&2 and Star Control 1&2. If you aren't aware of these games or their significancant contributions to the genre than I simply could not even begin to lend any insight with mere words. On the other hand the game does feel... Unfinished. It has blockbuster potential for a niche crowd, and without keymapping within the game's options it does have a particularly cumbersome control scheme, which very well could turn away even the most enthusiastic of novice players. I also found myself strongly desiring far more depth of interaction dynamics between the various species. If you haven't any experience with this type of game, you almost assuredly will dislike this game. For me though, two thumbs up.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												OK, good RTS type descendent of MoOII. You will run into a few problems though. The AI, DOES NOT LIKE TO LOSE. You WILL get a start point bordered on all sides by aggressive civilizations. HALF OR MORE of all worlds within easy warp distance will be inhabited by "remnants" (hostile powerful aliens) or one terrible planet or none habitable. HALF OR MORE or all colonies you establish that are not close to your capital will be destroyed by enemy raiders unless you have the credits to employ a large and useless early military that drags your economy down. The game WILL let you create a race with traits that will make it a completely unviable race. IF you do not research the agricultural/biodome line first, you will probably lose, but if you don't get to planetary defenses fast enough after, you will still lose.Good game, but still rough around the edges in the balance category. 7/10 - Fun but frustrateing.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												I bought this game 2 days ago and have played 14 hours of it, I still haven't finished my first game yet. The games are long but you are always kept busy between micro-managing each planet, and macro-managing your empire. The interface is not very intuative and is slightly buggy, but with a little practice it seems rather simple.The creating of your own unique ship's is a major part of the fun for me. Finding ways to optimize the standard ships is great fun, especially when a new teach finishes and a new strategy opens up.Overall I would say this game is an excellent space 4X game with very unique race, each with their own personalities, a large variaty of ships, and the pleasure of dominating your opponants on a galactic scale.

												Stardrive is a fun, innovative game with one of the best ship customization systems I've ever seen. That said, the game is horribly incomplete. number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												The spaceship customization in this game is almost unrivaled. Everything from gun placement to armor to generators can all determine outcomes in battles. It is an absolute blast to spend hours creating ships to annihilate your foes with. There are also different perks you get to choose from when you start that effect your gameplay, like being "robotic" where you race consumes no food but eats production instead.The only downsides of the game are that the rounds can be long. Really long. Like 3 hours depending on how fast/aggressive you are. Computers have an annoying habbit of constantly jumping planets when they are almost dead. Real pain to finish them off. Also, much of the game is focusing on taking over planets with something called "Doom Drops" where you fly a ton of soldier ships and just crash them into the planet to take it over (no spaceship fighting.) Its not a bad mechanic, but it somewhat invalidates the awesome spaceship creations you make and the computer (due to micromanagement) is REALLY good/annoying with them. You'll be pausing a lot to issue commands to keep up.Overall, still a lot of fun. Would defintely recommend.

												This game is fun and reminds me of a better version of Master of Orion. However there are some serious flaws and it appears that its only maybe 80% finished or so. Limited ship hulls especially orbital platforms. AI has problems sometimes doing things. Fun yes, But with a very steep learning curve. Building your own ships is fun at first but can be quite tedious. Moving them in combat formations even more so. some definate bugs with landing ground troops on planets and so on. The unfinished random events and bugs in this prevent it from being a breath of fresh air in a stangant genre and coming out like a waft of stale perfumed vapror of a fancy tomb.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This game isnt great. After being released a while ago it still feels like an unfinished beta version of the game. Based on the forums, it doesnt look like the developer will ever finish the game because they've already started on thier next one. The game freezes, crashes, wierd buggyness, confusing as hell and is not polished in a lot of areas, but that all being said, its a lot of fun. Think a much slower and less refined civ game based in space. I dont want to compare it to the other space games. I put it on easy mode, researched everything explored every nook and such and still didnt understand some of the mechanics. Then i built several massive dreadnaut class capital warships with intertial dampeners, filled one with nukes and another with the best shields and weapons money could buy and just walked through everything. That was fun. I really wish the devs would take the time to really finish this game, build in the tooltips and not make it impractical to research and such. Ship building is awesome, its a bit much for me but if you really get into it, theres some crazy things you can do with it. Resource management is like any other civ game. Its a bit quirky but theres some nice differences to set it apart from the rest. The diplomacy stuff is meh, I was never good at dimplomacy but the 'tone' option you have on all responses really is a neat thing. The slowness is a good and bad thing, sometimes a speed adjustment would be nice, but other times I couldnt hit the pause button quick enough. Aside from any other unpolished based complaints, my big issue was with the notification system. My fleet could have gotten into a huge ambush or intercepted by the 'remnant' forces and I would have never known. It got me quite a bit of times and I'd never want it to be like civ which I think has notification overload but there needs to be more. I had a smaller map and its just too much to keep track of. I dont know the cost of the game now, its definitely worth checking out, I only spent like 8 bucks on the sale so that was worth it, but dont expect it to be the next MoO and if you dont know what that is, then thats good, just go with it. I'll check it out six months from now and maybe I'll change my tone from 'threatening' to 'pleading' for forgiveness and like the wasteland 2 game I hope it happens, but this isnt even an early release. Good luck out there.-Sincerely, http://www.thecomic-community.com

												While perhaps not as deep or complex as other games in its category, and perhaps slightly derivative at times, with the Draylok Council and Human Federation being strangely reminiscient of Mass Effect's Asari and Human races, Stardrive still reperesents a good, accessible play for those who are unfamiliar with the vague "Civilizations in Space" genre. 												I'm writing a review because I see a lot of reviews saying "it's unfinished'.  I played it for almost 60 hours and I'm not sure what they are talking about.  It's a fun game for anyone who likes space exploration / building /  combat, micromanaging (somewhat, there's always the auto button for skipping that part of the game...), and building their own ships.  If you have played any of the earlier Civilization games (up through ~3), you know how to get a ship built fast and how important the details for your cities, er planets are for getting things done.  I had a blast and this game is in my Favorites list.  If you're struggling to get Space Empires V to run on Windows 7, give this one a try!

												Just another disappointed early access purchaser. I sank a decent number of hours into this game but that was mainly because the pace of the game is slow, and after a while I ran out of new content ( wasn't worried though as I knew it was early access - my mistake ).My advice, buy Stardrive2, it looks like how I assumed Stardrive1 was GOING to be before the developer(s) up and left it, abandoned. I'm just glad I got this game on sale 75% off, so I can't be too salty about it.EDIT:I have just played Stardrive 2They changed the best parts of Stardrive completely, turns no longer play in real-time, the shipyard is worse - however they did add the ability to add upgrades to modules which I liked, the research system meant that you couldn't unlock every tech in the game without a silly race attribute, the space combat is slow and boring, ground combat is simple and the graphical 'improvements' make the game look weirdly cheap.Bearing all this in mind...My new advice, do NOT buy Stardrive 2 unless you want a more MOO3 type game, do buy Stardrive 1 - when it goes on sale - and mod it, with a community mod or something. I've had much more fun playing Stardrive 1 and that's just what I've came to accept.I've changed my recommendation.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Abandoned before it was truly finished, and what is there, is actually just quality 4X gameplay - to a certain extent.The game offers some refreshing mechanics that work well and completely customized ship building 'FTL' style. Ships consist of internal blocks that can be populated by modules, of which placement is also important and a tactical aspect. The end result is a very enticing ship building and testing game, with a hint of 4X to tide you through to the nicest technologies and ships. If you are looking for a deep 4X, you are in the wrong place.On sale, I recommend this game. Get it cheap, or move on to something better.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												I love this game so much. It still feels like it's in dev because there's still enough bugs and patches that are needed but it's still playable. Sadly the game feels like there is so much more potential yet it hasn't or will not tap into.The game itself allows you to customize your own ships with a large variety of weapons, shields, armor, equipment, and whatnot. You can then make fleets of those ships and fight against other factions. The diplomacy in the game is better than what the civilization series has accomplished. You actually get rewarded quite well for being diplomatic instead of being completely warlike. Also the galaxy exploration is fun too. You can send out scouts looking for suitable planets for colonization and you can build your solar galaxy in between planets and can connect them with trade systems and territorial markers. I would highly recommend this game if you love sci-fi space battles and the civilization series.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												Stardrive is like your normal 4X strategy, often slow to start up, but then builds it's stride.Unlike other games, the combat is completely real time,  taking place on a top down view.  You are also giving different ship frames where you can customize how it is armored and armed square by square. It's an interesting thing, but this leads to a few problems.Ship battles don't really have any sort of micromanagement, even smaller ships turn slowly. Ship AI is also lacking.  Also building new ship designs is also a timesink, especially when constantly researching new weapons.  This would be a huge problem in multiplayer.. which unfortunately there is none.The game is still getting updates, but it's hard to justify a fullpricetag.If it's on sale, it's is worth the time.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												In two words - splendid idea, but flawed implementation.I stumbled across this game searching for a "Master of Orion" clone, as many would say. Eventually, all 4X games become compared to it.StarDrive has many positive aspects - friendly interface, interesting gameplay, starship constructor (in which alone, you'll spend hours, customizing your ships). But all-in-all, in my opinion, it failed to implement these into a balanced game. Notorious AI and ship movement, bugs, balancing issues, weak diplomacy. Abscence of a storyline is OK for me, neither MoO did have one, but StarDrive feels in every way incomplete. Short tech-tree, strategy flaws (you can win almost every game in minutes, by producing soldiers and landing them onto enemy homeworlds - no defence for that. Ka-pow! And the enemy is either extict, or thrown into a stone age.)Moreover - as of 1.15 patch, it seems that there'll be no more updates, as developer focused on a second installement. Some complained it was a hit-and-run move, but I sense logic there. No use of trying to sew together a Frenkenstein. It's far easier and wiser to start from scratch, avoiding mistakes learned. Looking forward to trying the second game out.My opinion - the game is worth trying out, although overpriced. But a good addition to a 4X collection when sold at a discount.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												I loved this game mainly because of the vast customization of ships. It did have some issues initially, but as updates have been released they have become increasingly less common. The technology tree was kinda small, but it was enough for me frankly because of the time it took to research the best things. Dynamic planets were also a cool positive that added some randomness to resource distribution throughout the galaxy. I do also know there are several mods out for this game that are free, but have never tried them. The main problem was with the game (imo) was the AI. They are not very intelligent and it can be really difficult beginning a new game because if you encounter a hostile race they will more than likely troop rush you and destroy you within 15 minutes. Lack of multiplayer was no big deal to me, but to some people I can see that as being a deal breaker.

What it really shines in is the ship construction. Once the tech tree starts to open up, the sky is the limit with what you can design your ships to do, though I generally end up doing the same strategies as some seem to be superior to others.Perhaps the pricetag is a little high, but I certainly wouldn't discourage anyone from getting this game, I find it very enjoyable.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												This game is a great accomplishment, the developer is just one guy.  You won't find another game like this.   Find me another game where you punch through enemy shields and armor,  and then begin to damage internals effecting ships performance as ship modules are destroyed.  Knock out engines and the ships adrift.  Hit ammunition and you have a powder keg destroying half your ship or causing a chain reaction.  Destroy reactor lose power.  Have all your weapons shut down on one side because how you designed your ship when it takes damage.  My favorite is watching a ship spin off with destroyed engines or spin firing all weapons straight into the enemy flee.  This game is the next level of stategy and sets a new benchmark. I can forgive the few problems with the game.What are your alternatives?  The same old game,  do some damage and just simply down hitpoints until a ship explodes. I want to experience all of the above.  I think everyone posting negative reviews are just proffesional haters.  Maybe even other developers who are like,"Uh-o if this game gets to big it will set the standard and we'll have to do allot more work."

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												To be clear, I'll say up front that I very much enjoyed this game, played it for over 200 hours, and intend to snap up its sequel as soon as it's available.  What drew me to it the most is its innovative and thorough approach to ship design and combat.  If you'd enjoy spending 20 thought-filled  minutes crafting a customized inter-system war machine, this one's for you.  I should add that watching said war machine ply its trade is beautiful and enjoyable as well.  I loved almost everything about the design and implementation of the space combat in StarDrive.  Its real-time approach encompasses fighters, boarding parties, attack, defense, reinforcements, re-arming, repairing, bombarment, trade, support structures, warp speed and manuevering.  However, I must also acknowledge that this game never overcame a certain lack of polish.  Confused AI, glitches, and underdeveloped or dead-ending side stories riddle the game.  In order to fully enjoy its excellent space combat system, you must learn how to work with the game's quirks and carefully guide the challenge level into an ideal range with practiced care.  I am amazed and impressed with what this game's creator(s) were able to accomplish.  At the same time, I can see why its metacritic score didn't make it to the 90s; its great strengths are forced to associate with a series of weaknesses.

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												Realtime 2D Space 4X. Ship customisation is awesome, planet micro is not. The AI can handle a lot for you which is great (and a must). Ship/Fleet management is overwhelming and not very  necessary given Stardrive's game mechanics  - which is disappointing. Research tree is unnecessarily complicated (i.e. it is poor but not as bad as Sins of a Solar Empire). Did you understand all the jargon and enjoy MoO2? - then this is your game. Endless Space is better than Stardrive in all aspects but Endless Space has a completely different ship combat mechanic and is turn-based. If combat is the make or break choice: choose Stardive if you want to control swarms of 2d ships, choose Endless space for battle strategy and awesome combat visuals. Get it only on sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This game is AWESOME. It really recaptures the whole vibe from my favorite game of all time, Master of Orion 2. Alas, it does not quite reach that height, but it certainly comes CLOSE. Closer perhaps than any other game of its type or genre. I just love building ships, designing how they work, what they use, the tactical considerations and concessions to various limitations.A lot of reviews criticize its lack of polish, but it is improving. There are community mods and expansions that extend the game considerably (I personally only use the Station Symmetry mod, the lopsided vanilla stations aggravate my OCD). I would say that it should have remained in "beta" for longer, but it it is still very fun to play.I would argue that it is actually a very stable game. There are scattered issues with the savegame, but nothing game-breaking. If you're having problems, don't forget to do the old "Verify integrity of game cache" option; I haven't seen that fail yet.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												While this is a great game worth a look, a ball was dropped somewhere that makes you feel like you bought half a game.    You can assume manual control over your "flagship" but this is sort of useless; I find myself never making use of the ability.  That, coupled with the fact that there's a game type selector but no game type except the default, tells me that this game started with the intent to develop something akin to StarFlight or Star Control II, but that inability to manage scope led it to becoming just another Sins of a Solar Empire clone.   That said, the AI is challenging, though it tends to make odd choices at times.   Unfortunately, the races are very predictable in behavior, and seem a bit like ripoffs themselves.   The Kulrathi warrior bear race reminds me a little much of the Kilrathi warrior cat race from old Wing Commander.   There's a race of squid-beings that have ships and philosophy very similar to the Reapers from Mass Effect.  I did enjoy playing this game for one or two playthroughs, and the modification of the ships is an interesting mechanic, but I found myself going back to Sins of a Solar Empire to get this sort of fix.   Between the lack of creativity on the alien races and the clear false-start of creating an "adventure" mode, I was never able to shake the feeling that the game was completed halfway and the rest was just phoned in.   It's a game worth playing if you can grab it on Steam Sale, but it's also a lesson in how scope creep can turn a great idea into an unfinished project.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Game is absolutely tons of fun, when I first got it I racked up the hours bloody quick, good thing I was on holidays.I'm a huge fan of space basd strategy games and usually go for 4x turn based ones. I purchased this on a whim. Its all real time and done from a top down perspective, which I found unepexted and, at first unapealing. However, as I learned my way around the contrls and began combat, I realised how much fun this game can seriously get. The combat in this is tons and tons of fun, least of all because of the creative control you have on your ships. You get the blueprint of your ship, and then fill its insides with weapons, power, bridges, the lot. You then test your design out in combat. It has great visuals and beautiful weapon effects, all the races ships feel different and look cool. Its only downside is Empire building and the economy is pretty shallow. Buildings are generic and colonisation is always the same.The planets serve only as the economic base for your fleets, which you will be building enmasse

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Stardrive is one of the better 4X style games i've played. It's got a fluid "turn-based" system which keeps you informed and able to calculate, without slowing down the game. I find it a good blend of the 4X and RTS genres, retaining some of the better parts from both. Every 4X game i've played has had its flaws, and Stardrive is no exception. But out of the games i've played, i find it my favorite. Definitely a good buy.

number of helpful: 8 of 21 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												It's been very difficult for me to get into 4x games. I tried Galactic civ 2 a little while ago and got confused as anything, tried to play a bit of Sins of a solar empire but was completely overwhelmed with how much was involved in playing. Then I picked up Endless space, which I'm really wanting to get into but the learning curve again is huge for me. The only 4x I've enjoyed and have found easy to play but not spent a great deal of time on is Civ 5, which I plan on going back to sometime but for some reason I'm set on learning how to play a SPACE 4x. With Stardrive, I think I've found my 4x space training wheels. I've not found it as complex as the others, not turn based and for me, it's easing me into how 4x games essentially work. I can't say much about the negativity surrounding the game because I'm only new to the genre but as a game, I'm finding that it functions great so far. Graphically I can not complain, the music and sounds are nice. I'm sure as I play more, I'm going to find things I don't like and once I get used to the genre I'll start playing other 4x space games then look back on this and make comparisons but for now, this seems like a great entry level game to the genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I'm somewhat on the fence about this game, but I think I can say I recommend it with reservations.The real-time approach is often a mistake in making a 4X game; StarDrive manages to avoid most of the big problems that other recent attempts (most notably the terribly disappointing Armada 2526) have had. The mechanics make sense, and the player can make informed choices to wring out advantages to actually win battles, wars, and the game. Custom ship designs are a key part of the value proposition of the game, and the implementation here is meaty and satisfying.Those good things said, the game has some big flaws in usability/playability. There is often only one way to perform an action  (scrap/refit a ship, scroll the map) when there should be several; information displays like the known-planets list and ships list are missing key features. Also, while the ship design module is a lot of fun early in the tech tree, as ships get larger the lack of any automated support makes filling in all the boxes of a design tedious instead of fun.I picked StarDrive up as part of the holiday sale, and I can say it was worth the discounted price to me, but I'm not sure it would be worth full price.

												I see a lot of negative reviews for this game and I really don't agree with them. This is a solid game with a very distinct art style. It looks really good and yet very simple, which is not a bad thing. The game is very easy to learn and is quite deep in it's ship customization and you will spend many hours designing and perfecting your ship designs. There is nothing more satisfying than having your custom badass capitalship send out a swarm of your custom fighters and totaly anhialate an enemy fleet.Compared to a lot of other 4X games, Stardrive does not have as big of a techtree, there is still plenty of things to research but compared to games like Endless Space it's far from enough. One thing I really miss is more ways to improve your planets and concidering all the buildingspace you have left, there is room for a lot more.Pros:- Short learning curve- Deep shipdesign- Real-time gameplay- AddictingCons:- Not enough to research- Ground battles- Game crash after a few hours of play- Save files are way to big

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												I really wanted to like StarDrive.  It reminded me of the old Stars! game for Windows 3.1, where you would define your alien race, expand, conquere, research and design new ship layouts.  It sounded like a great modern update.  But after playing for a while, expanding a lot, and making a large fleet, I tried to attack a small faction and lost for no good reason.  It feels like there's a "correct" way to play this game and they never tell you anything about how to play it.  For instance, to conquer a planet, you have to take out the ships guarding it, and then send colonists over in separate transport ships to fight on the ground, which is heavily favoured to the defender.  You have to outnumber them like 10-1 to have a hope of taking the place.  So after spending an untold effort in trying to take ONE planet from a small faction, my faction gets into a civil war and my homeworld gets heavily attacked, at which point I lost all interest in this game.The mechanics are clunky and not at all expained.  To top it off, it seem like a lot of features where left unfinished in favour of working on the sequel, so overall, I would say avoid.  I mean really, 75% of the 4x games on steam are space based like this.  Search games by tag and find a good one to play.

												The game reminds me of MOO2, but it's in real time.  The ship customization is a strong point because it really matters how you build your ship. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 26, 2013
												Now that it's been officially released, I am going to recommend to everyone who sees this and enjoys 4X games to give StarDrive a test.StarDrive is a game of immense depth. You are provided the option of designing your entire fleets to your specifications -- you can create ships using a variety of weapon types and defenses. The game even facilitates some very interesting and not inherently obvious strategies surrounding your ship construction.The gameplay itself is basically a 4X RTS/TBS hybrid. "Empire" related things, such as economy, diplomacy, and colony management are done in timed turns where each turn is something like five seconds. "Ship" related things, such as flight, combat, and eventual destruction are handled in real time.This game sucked away more than 100 hours my play time before it was even released. It can do the same for you, too, if you would like it to.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												I really wanted to like StarDrive.  It reminded me of the old Stars! game for Windows 3.1, where you would define your alien race, expand, conquere, research and design new ship layouts.  It sounded like a great modern update.  But after playing for a while, expanding a lot, and making a large fleet, I tried to attack a small faction and lost for no good reason.  It feels like there's a "correct" way to play this game and they never tell you anything about how to play it.  For instance, to conquer a planet, you have to take out the ships guarding it, and then send colonists over in separate transport ships to fight on the ground, which is heavily favoured to the defender.  You have to outnumber them like 10-1 to have a hope of taking the place.  So after spending an untold effort in trying to take ONE planet from a small faction, my faction gets into a civil war and my homeworld gets heavily attacked, at which point I lost all interest in this game.The mechanics are clunky and not at all expained.  To top it off, it seem like a lot of features where left unfinished in favour of working on the sequel, so overall, I would say avoid.  I mean really, 75% of the 4x games on steam are space based like this.  Search games by tag and find a good one to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 19, 2013
												Un juego RTS x4 del espacio, probablemente uno de los mejores que han salido en mucho tiempo y, en lo personal, el mejor que he probado.  Lo mejor del juego y destacable sin duda, es su personalizacion en cuanto a naves.  Con un sistema de rejilla, puedes modificarlas y diseñarlas como quieras y las opciones son muy amplias. Por no mencionar que la IA tambien usara tus propios diseños contra ti en futuras partidas.Otro punto a favor son los mods, es muy facil modificar el juego por uno mismo, y en cuanto a mods hechos por modders hay algunos muy buenos que añaden toneladas de opciones, armas y modulos nuevos para tus naves. Asi como edificios y tecnologias.En conclusion, un juego muy bueno RTS, con algunos fallos pero que estan siendo corregidos por los desarrolladores (el juego sigue en desarrollo y parcheado casi diariamente). Lo recomiendo al 100%.
